The nose is slightly boozy with some cinnamon bread and almonds. There is also a little funk and pears. The taste is doughy with black tea and toffee. A sweet finish to this well balanced brew. Well made with high carbonation and a surprisingly smooth body.
Old notes. Pours a clear dark brown with a white head. Nose is toffee malts, caramelized sugars and dark fruits, yeasty. Sweet in flavor and following the aroma. It was alright.

deep brown/amber with a thick cream head.  nose is dried fruits, peaches and apricots mostly, light caramel, and spices.  very smooth on the palate, clove, dried fruits, and yeast stand out, along with the peach and clove.

750ml bottle
Aroma: sugar, caramel, fruity
Taste: caramel, earthy, burnt sugar
Not a bad beer, but it was on the thin side. I like more complexity in my Dubbels.

Bottle. Pours a muddy brown color with a foamy off white head. Nose is sweet malt and brown sugar, raisins, plums, dates. Palate is smooth and fluffy upfront with a thick chewy finish. Flavors of dark fruits, chocolate, dates.

pours copper with a nice thick head and some good carbonation. malt aromas and abbey style yeast come through the pour. light and slightly sweet with some fizzy carbonation on your tongue. safe for a dubbel but very enjoyable.

Although relatively light and uncomplex for any Belgian style, this dubbel is nonetheless pleasantly sweet with a good malt profile and a touch of hoppiness. Not very aromatic. A tad heavy in the palate for the flavor.
Light sweetness.  Belgian yeast is prominent.  Standard brown color.  Simple, some fruit and malt.  Light, for a dubbel.  Not bad.

750ml bottle, shared by robotopera. Hazy brown-red color. Minimal off-white head. A tiny bit of lace. Nice, spicy caramel aroma. Lighter crisp carbonation. Good light texture. Drinkable. Some citrus. A good, interesting dubbel.
750ml bottle.  Pours a dark orange amber.  Aroma of caramel, grain, dried fruit, vanilla.  Flavor is molasses, toffee, grape, spice.  Overall a good beer, but nothing special.

Pours a dark brown with a thin fizzy off white head.  Aroma is very faint raisin, sweet malts and light hop.  Taste is somewhat thin bodied, well carbonated, sweet malts, light raisin and dark fruits.  Everything is too tame for me.  Everything is subtle, would like a little more complexity.

Bottle. Moderate malt notes of nutty and caramel, ligt to moderate flowers for the hops, light dough for the yeast, with hints of raisin, cherry, red wine and brown sugar. Head is small, fizzy, light beige with no lacing and is fully diminishing. Color is murky, red/brown. flavor starts lightly sweet and moderately acidic, then finishes faintly sweet and lightly acidic and bitter. palate is medium, a little slick with a lively carbonation. The best quality of this Abbey Dubbel for me is the subtle yet assertive aromas and flavors.
Very nice sweet aroma wheaty and tiny hints of coconut. Looks awesome, cloudy brown body and a foamy tan head. Heavy body with complex spices.

(bottle)  Compliments of Keg_Juggler.   Mild aroma of cola, cherry and sweet malt.   Deep amber complexion with dissipating tan head.  Flavors of cola, cherry, Belgian malt, black pepper & spice.  Great palate with mild carbonation.  Overall an outstanding Dubbel and great find!
opaque coppery red beer with minimal head and lacing but highly carbonated, notes of bread, yeast, wine, spice, clove, raisin, pepper and caramel among others, very melodic brew and highly drinkable
Deep red beer with just a hint of malt aroma. Not impressed with the low malt flavor and mild hops. Just ok.

22 oz bottle: Pours a light yellow with a nice white head and lots of CO2 release. Aroma was light but I also have a cold. Taste was smooth and spicy, interesting and a great beer for food. Very robust and complex for a "light" beer. Nice work.
Sweet and malty as expected.  Golden-brown in color with off-white head.  A decent dubble hints dubbel, hits right on, tho a bit light.  Not bad.
Draft in goblet. Pours amber brown with beige head. Aroma is caramel malts, ethers, grapish. Taste is sweet and  ends a little sour. Flat and medium bodied. Tasty with a long finish.

(750ml bottle thanks to Dixonian) cloudy orange with soapy tan head. Nose of cream, caramel, raisins and a bit of hairspray. Taste of rotten corn, cream, raw grains, a bit of raisins and a creamy finish.

Bottle shared by my neighbor. Pours coppery brown; takes a bit of an active pour to get a good head, which quickly fades. Nose of golden and red raisins, mild spice. Caramel and toffee malt notes. Some hop presence. Not very complex.

Wow, pheonol much? As a gift I really wanted to like this but the bandaid aroma mixed with a ton of sweetness and the clove smelling like a spice rack that needed cleaning just made this one a beer I didnt want to spend much time with

Bottle. Poured a rich ran. Nose has hints of raisins, and Belgian yeast. Starts subtle, Inobtrusive, a bit thin in mouthful. Middle opens up with some real quality notes. Subtle but solid especially with a bit of warmth which then opens up a slightl citrusy twang.

Draft at Bavarian Lodge. Cloudy brown color. S;ight;y fruity and sugary smell. hard to decide what I want to discuss first. After that first sip, I set the glass down and have a strawbery aftertaste. Sweet but not sugary. Slight molasses and brown malt flavor. Any alcohol is well masked until the middle of the goblet. Smidgen of weizen yeast ester. Fruit aftertaste lost after the first sips. Really nice, but i cant say its that exceptional.

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into Snifter.

Appearance: Dark orange-red (almost a pinkish head) with a very thick, light tan head.

Aroma: Plum, raisins, molasses, clove and spicy hops. Slightly metallic. Boozy.

Taste: Somewhat sweet and syrupy caramel, dark fruitiness (plum & raisins), with just the lightest spicy touch at the end. Taste just seems muted overall.

Palate: Despite some syrupiness, this is way too watery. Moderately high carbonation. Much more warming than 7.5% abv would indicate. Finish is not dry at all. Wow, the mouthfeel really misses the mark.

Overall: Between the light flavor and the horrible mouthfeel (for a Belgian at least), this completely let me down. I am a huge Sierra Nevada fan and a pretty big Trappist fan as well (even if this is not quite Trappist), but this does not at all live up to what either SN or the Monks are capable of.

750 ml bottle shared by Goldtwins.  Pours a deep woody brown- clear, with a nice fluffy beige head- lasting.  Aroma is nig big fruity esters- rum-raisin, dried plum then spices, without getting solvent, or fusel- light phenol balance, with a big toasty and fruity malt backbone.  Flavor is toasty, nice restrained fruitiness, airy saline phenolics cutting through the sweet caramel malts, biscuit and bready- slight burnt toast, and a nice airy medium dry finish.  One of the best Dubbels I have had.

A solid entry into the dubbel category. Pours deep garnet, full and foamy head that lingers nicely. Nose offers lovely aromas of dark fruit, caramel malt, and hints of peppery spice. Aroma is pleasant but on the subdued side.  Carbonation is lucious and Slight crispness, a lot of palate sticking maltiness. This beer is sweet, not in a "sugar buzz" way, but in a "sticky, coat your palate" way. The flavor profile is good, matches the aroma, down to the subdued part. This tastes like a solid dubbel, but with the volume turned down 2 notches. Its good, but not milder. Probably better for drinking the whole 750ml bottle, but less satisfying in a 12 oz pour.  A good entry to the style though, and I wouldnt turn down a glass.
Draft at beer nutz.  Minimal head.  Aroma of coriander, belgium yeast notes.  Med sweetness, lite bitter.  Ave carbonation.  Ends kind of spicy.  Some slight banana notes.
Tap at Blind Tiger. Smells of plum wine... Delicious. Light carb,  a touch of grain, plum, clove,  and thyme. Very nice! Unique.

Pours redish brown, with a tan head. Aroma is malt, brown sugar, and fruit. Flavor is malt, fruit, sugar, raisins, and pepper. Medium to light body, Wish it were heavier. Overall, a nice easy to drink dubbel.
Bottled sample.  Not my favorite style but appreciated this nonetheless.  Great tasting dubbel.

Pretty good beer. Let it warm a bit out of the fridge. Poured with a nice sized, foamy, frothy, fluffy, tan head that settled out after a bit and a little lace. Color is a hazy, medium amber. Aroma is kind of like the label description, but I dont get the clove - lots of malt, caramel, some other spice, dark ripe fruit. Flavor is like nose, dominated by the caramel sweetness, although thats not over done. Theres some bitterness and a bit of tang to balance. Body is good and carbonation is a tad light. Finish is like flavor, maintains its pleasance and is of medium length. Good for slower drinking shorter sessions.

Bottle.  Pours murky brown with thin tan head.  Aroma of Belgian yeast and candied sugar.  Heavy spice flavor with tons of dark fruit.  Thinner body than I expected.  Still a good representation of the style.  Better as it warms.

This one pours a clear golden, orange color.  Aroma is of malts and dark fruits up front with some brown sugar and yeast.  Flavor is of dark fruit, molasses, malts, yeast, and caramel.  It seems rather light or "watered down" which tends to happen in the Americas.  Decent brew though.

Bottle. Pretty much your good standard dubbel. Hazy mahogany color with a thick, creamy white head capping off the beer. Pleasant aroma of raisin and yeasty biscuit with cinnamon. Crisp peppery flavor that is well-balanced with malt sweetness and nutmeg and spice. Ends clean. Slightly metallic.

medium brown with large white head.  nose of belgian esters with dark candi sugar.  low bitterness before a nice ester component with alcohol providing a touch of distraction but mostly warmth and a relatively dry finish that makes this very drinkable.

Bottle pours medium brown with moderate white head and nice lacing.  Aroma malt and Belgian yeast.   Taste caramel, slight brown sugar, bread., some spice.  Really did not get much fruit taste at all.  Palate well carbonated and slightly thick.  Brief finish of malts and a slight dullness.  Alcohol well concealed.
Billed as complex but I found this very average with minimal complexity.

Bottle. Poured a clear dark orange color with a light tan head. Smelled of brown sugar, subdued spices, and toffee. Light to medium bodied and slightly sweet. There was also a touch of brine. Dark fruity flavors accented by distinct clove that lingered a bit.

750ml Bottle:  Aroma of dark malt, dark ripe fruit, yeast, and some caramel sweetness, but non of the "layered mix of fruit and spice, with hints of clove, raisin, and black pepper" claimed.  Poured deep amber/orange in color with a medium-sized, loose, tan head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Hazy or cloudy.  Flavor is light to medium sweet and slightly bitter.  Tastes of malt, yeast, spices, slight dark ripe fruit, and vegetables.  Medium body.  Dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Lightly sweet, yeast, malt, and slight dark ripe fruit finish is dry.  7.5%ABV is completely hidden throughout.

Pours dark muddy brown with ruby red edges. Smells malty, touches of caramel and a good Belgian yeast smell, sweet and fruity. Tastes primarily malty with a sweet, bready characteristic. Full-bodied with an oily texture and decent carbonation, Ovila Dubbel finishes with vinous dryness.
On tap at tap. Soft bready caramelized dubbel.  Some Clove and raisen.  Nice brew

750 mL bottle. Pours a dark orange-brown with long-lasting khaki head. The aroma is a dry, toasty maltiness, some raisin, a little clove, vanilla, a little bit of caramelized sugar, tollhouse cookies, a bit of an earthy note, and a nice herbal alcohol scent. The flavor is mellow malt with a caramel tinge; it is restrained and doesnt approach the cloying sweetness that other American dubbels get. Quite a bit of yeasty spiciness dances around in there, too, with clove, pepper, anise, even a little bit of sassafras. The finish is semi-dry, with vanilla and raisin notes along with a mild earthy bitterness. The aftertaste is sweet alcohol and doesnt last very long. Pretty good beer, this.

Tasted 8/11/11. 750ml cork and cage bottle. The first pour is rather clear with a brown amber hue. Dense cream colored head. Aromas of cooked sugar and dark berries. Medium to full bodied with a sweet malt note and a bitter astringent effervescence. Really nice fruity nuances and a spicy kick in the middle palate. Good roll between the sweet, bitter and tart flavors. The tingling carbonation lingers in the finish along with a sticky, cloying estery flavor. Well done!

Pours a ruddy brown with a tall, foamy beige head that quickly falls back to 1 finger of creamy bubbles has good retention from there and leaves decent bits of lacing. Aroma is dark fruit, bready yeast, sweet caramel, date nut bread and ripe tree fruit. Flavor is sweet malt, caramel, toasted nuts and clove. It gets pretty spicy  a little anise, and strong in the dark fruit toward the finish. Palate is medium bodied, has a moderate, but sharp carbonation kinda syrupy entry and dry, but slightly sticky and slick finish. Not bad.

On tap at Clark Street Ale House. Pours a brownish copper with a small off white head. Aroma is malty, sweet candy and bready with some bits of candied dark fruit and just a bit of spice. Flavor is much the same, the sweet candy fruit being prominent and picking up some spiciness towards the finish which is a bit weak and boring, but ok. Medium body and a soft carbonation. Not super impressed but not bad.

Corked bottle. Pour cloudy light golden colour with good head.  A great blend of a dubbel and candy, light fruit, hops, and spice.  Superior for the style and excellent drinkability.  I would seek this one out and use it to transition Coors people toward good beer.

Clear brown in color with a touch of copper.  Thin off white head.  Slight aroma of alcohol and dried fruit.  Kinda cherry like in aroma.   Flavor has similar alcohol bite with some pepper notes.  Finishes dry on the palate.  Overall, very tasty and darker than expected.

Tried from tap and bottle form.  Both times mehtastic! Clear dark brown pour, lasting thick carbonation and a nice sweet brown sugar/malt aroma. Flavor is light vegetal malt, some sweet sugar and finished thin and watery with a little spice on the aftertaste.

Hazy amber brown pour - tight head. The aroma is earthy and a little bit spicy with some light fruity character. Very estery and a little bit spicy as well. There is a lot of peppery spice and a nice light peppery character. There was a bit of soft light spice. Well attenuated and very lovely brew.

Aroma: fairly subtle; dark fruits, caramel, dates and figs, dark sugar.  Pours deep burgundy with a thick off-white head, very good retention, dissipates to a thin but stable layer of foam, good clarity.  Flavor is very smooth; fruity and malty, figs, dark sugar, raisins, caramel.  Alcohol is very well hidden, incredibly smooth and drinkable.  Medium-medium/full body, moderately high carbonation, velvety texture, effervescent.
Madly and slice aroma with a light hint of cinnamon. Hazy red-orange color with a medium tan head. Spicy malt beginning that lasts until the finish.

(Dégustation offerte par rodenbach99)  Le liquide a une robe aux couleurs de la dubbel classique.  La tête mousseuse résiste quelques secondes.  Le nez sarticule autour de malts caramélisés avec une présence fine de fruits et dépices.  Le goût est peu différent : les céréales grillées et les fruits dominent.  La levure donne encore quelques épices.  Une touche de caramel brûlé remonte à la surface.  En bouche, le liquide a un corps moyen avec une bonne effervescence et une texture légère.  La finale est douce avec quelques notes amères fantomatiques.

Description: Dubbel brassée par Sierra Nevada en collaboration avec labbaye de New Clairvaux . 
Comment: Bouteille de 750ml, bouchon de liège, achetée à Burlington. 
Visuel: Cette bière est brune avec des fines bulles qui montent à la surface avec une grande vélocité. 
Olfactif: Un mélange épicé et de chocolat. 
Gustatif: Les fruits secs sentremêlent avec des noix. La carbonation est importante, la bière prend de lexpansion en bouche. 
Résumé: Textbook dubbel. 
Note: 7/10

750 ml corked and caged bottle.  Served in a DFH Signature glass, the beer pours a hazy mahogany color with an inch and a half frothy light tan head.  The head stays around a long time, but there isnt much lacing at all.  Aroma is caramel malt, dark fruit and some clove and brown sugar.  The aroma is weak at first, but does get stronger the beer warms up (I did let this sit for about 15 minutes out of the fridge before opening it).  The brew tastes like dark fruit (raisins, figs), caramel and bready malt, peppery spice and brown sugar.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, its creamy and a bit slick with high carbonation.  Theres a little too much carbonation for my liking, but it doesnt hurt the beer too much.  I think its a decent brew, but for $9.99 Im not sure if Id buy it again at that price.

bottle @ azwine 3/24/11.

cherry tinted coppery brown with an off white hear. clear at first but grows increasingly hazy toward the bottom.

aromas of grain, plummy fruit, sweet cherries, florals, cinnamon and warming spiciness, vanilla, yeast (but not overwhelming), faint choco, sulfurous smoke and some grassy notes.

the palate is very dry... much drier than any other dubbel i can remember... sessionable even.

the flavor is quite feminine and well balanced... all of the notes from the aroma carry over at some point... add in a touch of grain, woodiness and earthy peppers with a vanilla tapioca aftertaste (the real stuff not instant!)

Pours dark brown with an off white head. 
Aroma is tart, leather, small amount of coriander. 
Taste is tart and lightly bitter. 
Light mouthfeel, kind of sticky, tart. Hints of coffee and chocolate.  Fizzy carbonation.

Bottled sample via and shared with oakbluff. Dark red in colour with medium carbonation. Aromas are of pale, toasted, and caramel malts, orchard fruit, and a bit of spice. Flavours are malt forward, backed by notes of poached pears, mace, caramel, and some peppery hops. Medium bodied with a slightly bitter finish. Less spicy and more hoppy than a traditional abbey dubbel, but more drinkable (on its own) in my opinion. Quite nice.

On tap at 1 for the road.  Looks like a brown ale.  Not sure but I think it has a rather perfumy background. Seems a little plastic on the palate.  Not over the top but still is not as well behaved as a real abbey belgian dubbel.  Some co2.  Also, I detectg a little bandaid in there. Bitterness begins to build as the session continues. Yep, not quite up to snuff as the real dubbels but it is certainly much more welll behaved than most of the american wannah bees.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottle 750ml. @ PBF 2011Light unclear medium to dark amber colour with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, fully lasting, off-white to beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, caramel, nutty, dusty, moderate hoppy, moderate yeasty, phenol notes. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, malty and hoppy, yeasty notes, dry, very clean. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20110702]

Bottle [750ml] shared with HogTownHarry, JoeMcPhee, jerc & mabel -- c/o JoeMcPhee. Pours a hazy orange-copper with an average size lasting off-white head. Mild aroma is sugary sweet along with yeast, sweet malt, a hint of spice and some dark fruit. Flavour, like the aroma, is sugary sweet with sweet malt, yeast , dark fruit and a hint of spices -- somewhat simple for the style. Alcohol is well hidden. Average to medium bodied. Not great, just good.

[3815-20110708] 1pt9.4floz bottle. Sweet apple sauce floral perfume aroma. Slightly hazy, dark red amber body with a medium-lasting foamy off-white head. Toasted sweet floral malt flavour. Medium body. Pleasant. (7/3/6/3/13) 3.2
Overheard: "Its also an analgesic." "... Anal Jesus?" "Hey, finally, we have a band name!"
(c/o JoeMcPhee, w/ him, blankboy, HogTownHarry, jerc)

The aroma is malty, earthy, spicy, light fruit.  The appearance is a nice opaque dark amber, off-white head.  The flavor is malty, yeasty, earthy, caramel (almost burnt sugar), fruit.   The finish is spicy, yeasty, resin hops.  Medium in body.  Not great, but not bad.

Ovila Dubbel is a hazy, deep amber beer with a light khaki head that has excellent retention and lacing.  It has a slightly funky, grainy and fruity with notes of apple, pear and clove.  Its medium bodied and smooth with a crisp finish.  It tastes fruity and spicy with notes of apple and cinnamon.  A light wooden bitterness cones in at the finish.  Light phenol is detected in the aftertaste.  Its really smooth, mellow and satisfying.

2011-07-08. Lovely brown body, modest tan head. Pleasant flavour, sweet malt core, sugar notes with caramel touches. 7+ Aroma is similar, sweet malt, sugary accents. 7+ Smooth average plus palate. Pretty basic dubbel, but enjoyable. Bottle shared by JoeMcPhee
Taster @ Chucks. Tasty but super malty. Almost too sweet . Would be interested in the quad.

750ml c&c picked up at the local state store 
Appearance: Pours hazy dark brown/amber with a big long lasting head and good lacing 
Aroma: Malty, Belgian yeast, ripe fruit and peppery 
Taste: Malts, peppery, ripe fruits with a nice dry slightly bitter finish 
Very nice and enjoyable.
Foggy mahogany color/ lasting beige head. Sweet, spicy,  yeasty, dark fruit aromas. Medium bodied with a soft co2. Easy drinking brown sugar, spicy belgian, rootbeer flavors--
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: 750 ml bottle from Plaza Liquors - Pours a clear deep mahogany color with a one and a half finger thick light tan head.  Light lacing.  Aroma is light esters and hops with a hint of spice.  I mean real light.  Flavor is lightly sweetened malt and esters.  Again, not much flavor.  Finish is quite smooth.  Medium body.  A decent beer, but not a lot going on.

Appearance: deep mahogany, garnet, and ruby. Off-white head is bubbly and frothy. Swirls nominal.

Nose: bready sweet with raisins, dates, plums, and prunes. Maraschino cherries. Spiced red apple skins. Figs and fig cake. Dried black cherries.

Palate: dried cherries, raisins, figs, and chocolate in the finish. Spice mingles. Grabs sides of cheeks with balanced tart tannins. More dry chocolate cake in the finish. Maraschino cherries in the breath. Juicy along the sides, dry in the middle. Sophisticated. Essence of biting into juicy succulent plums. Date cake. Slow stream of bubbles from first quaff to last.

Final Thoughts: a lot of time, love, faith, and good will have gone into bringing the Ovila Abbey beers to our tables and our bars. Finally. As with all good things in life, twas certainly worth the wait.

First thing you notice is a warming alcohol taste, followed by a slight taste of apples and something spicy I cant place, all over a malt background. That Belgian yeast taste is also present throughout. Another solid beer from Sierra Nevada.
Bottled. Hazy amber colour, small beige head. Aroma is caramel, toffee, sweet malts, and also some yeastyness. Flavour is toffee, mild sweetness as well as some yeast andvspices. Rather pleasant.

750ml-pours a foamy light tan head with trailing lace and hazy amber color.  Aroma is medium malt-brown sugar, dark fruit, slight spice.  Taste is medium malt-roasty/brown sugar, slight spice hops.  Medium body.

Bottle. Which Ive had for a bit and the darn thing eluded me.  I checked my cellar three times in the last week looking for it.  It wasnt in the beer fridge in my office.  It wasnt in the food fridge in the kitchen.  But it was!  It was hiding on the door, sneaky bastard.  Anyhow, pours a clear ruby and copper hued amber with a medium sized soft white head.  Sweet caramel and malt, nice and dense.  Nice toasty yeast notes.  Smooth, a touch sweet, light fruit and very soft hints of warm banana as it moves to the finish.  Very nice and easy drinking.

Very traditional abbey dubbel.  Light carbonation and rich brown/red color.  Taste is nutty, lightly sweet with a dry finish and all of the classic flavors associated with good belgian yeast; spicy, doughy, candied.  Very nice.
Unclear copper with a small tanned head. Jelly fruit candy, some dried fruits, toasted bread and very slight wood. A bit weakin its flavours but otherwise a good dubbel.

Had as a draft pourr dark brown aale with a beige head flaavors of caramel, toffee and dark fruit sting the nostrils, taste follows the aroma profile, doesnt taste like 7.5% beer.  Really good abbey double.
UPDATED: JUL 6, 2011 Tastes just like a typical abbey dubbel should taste. Sweet caramelly belgian sugars with a malt backbone. Tastes forced carbonates however. Great job Sierra Nevada!

First off, this gives me one more reason to hate corks. The bulbous part that sticks out broke off of this one, forcing me to remove the cracking cork w/ a corkscrew. It wasnt the end of the world but I am disappointed that a brewery w/ generally intelligent views toward packaging would use more expensive and inferior technology. I wish I could say the beer inside was worth it but it really isnt. It pours a slightly cloudy chestnut brown w/ only a wisp of head. The nose here is slightly tart and raisiny. Once tasted, the beer is a bit sweet and sticky and sluggish on the palate due to only mild carbonation. This offers neither the vibrant fruity, spicy yeast character nor the light but creamy texture of a good Belgian. A slight metallic off-note takes things down even further. This is a huge disappointment in a fancy package.

Bottled 750ml (PBF)
Dark amber color, small beige head. Raisiny, caramelly aroma. Medium-bodied. Raisins, plums, candy sugar. Active carbonation. Decent imitation of  trappist dubbel.

From the wire-caged, corked tall bottle.  The pour is a murky mahogany-brown with a good head that settles quickly. The aroma is thin but with a deep whiff I get caramel malts, nuts, raisins, and pepper.  The body is around medium with the slick, creamy quality of yeast dancing on the tongue. The taste has a nice sweet, dark fruitiness with a peppery after thought.  A nice take on the style.

Strong aroma of grapes and malts to begin with while the appearance is brownish amber.  The flavor is of dark fruit and subtle all around.  The overall score for this is very good and not over the top but still a great Dubbel.

Pour is a dark brown with a large tan head.  Aroma is some dark fruit and a bit of caramel.   Flavor is again more caramel, some brown sugar and spice.  I was going to give this a lower score for flavor but it grew on me the more I had.  Still kinda weak flavor for the style and high price point just puts this in the ok department.

75cl bottle. Glowing red-brown with a light beige head. Lightly spicy yeast with some dried fruit, bread crust and burn caramel in the aroma. The flavor is on the dry side and shows nicely restrained but expressive yeast character. Lean and tight in body but with enough texture to keep things round. I didnt expect this to be a flop, but I dont think I anticipated that it would be this well done. A well-designed, executed, and restrained dubbel. Its not going to overthrow the Belgian greats, but puts in a very respectable showing and can definitely hang with them.

750 ml bottle bought at the Foothill State Store. Pours a brown/red color with a large beige head. The aroma is dusty, with some caramel and sweet nutty malts. The flavor is a smooth and  tasty dry fruity malt dominated brew, some caramel and toffee, very smooth and easygoing. A nice brew.

Aroma of apple, caramel, brown sugar, rum and a little oak. Appearance is ruddy dark cola brown with light tan head, after settling. The flavor really resembles mulled cider, with the clove, apple and caramel notes; the finish has a nice light sugar and alcohol burn, tapering off with a bit of rum and almonds. The palate is very bubbly for an Belgian style American beer. Very nice.

This is a beer within a beer. Immediately calling to mind the infamous spectre of the Tucc de Garde, which none of you have had because youre all fucking idiots. Ive had it, thrice! Which is to say Ive never had it. Well, twice. Thats right, I just changed my mind thrice. No, I didnt change my mind. Well, twice. 
  
Back to the beer, or as I like to call it, malt concentrate, hop nog, or cream of yeast. This beer looks very gamey, and no less sinewy. This beer will have you tasting the curb before you can say "Id like to get my pretzel prostate examined thrice. No I wouldnt. Well, twice." The smell is redolent of old chair, crimson, carrots, rickety bridge, Crispix, clouds, karats, and the year of our Lord 1422, and by our Lord I mean Lord Byron. 

One doesnt taste this beer as much as one siphons it up the ass. And by ass, I mean your ass. Although dont let it touch the prostate, its far too alcoholic. But if one were to taste it orally, it would taste thusly: colon, cologne, Cologne, colonies, cola, Colgate (college), Spygate, Kolsch, coal, raisins, Colgate (toothpaste), coal ash, cold, semi-colons, Watergate, Colin Powell, and old chair. Gimme, gimme, gimme a man after midnight. 

This reminds one of a mastiffs boner, in that it is immaculately conceived and complex in taste. This beer promises nothing and delivers everything, including gonorrhea and an above average credit score. This is a prefect beer, by which I mean it is only appropriate in certain prefects in China. Its far from perfect. Which is to say it is flawless. A great dubbel if Ive ever had one, and I have, thrice! No, I never have. Wait, yeah I have, thrice.
Big bottle from Liquor Loft.  Butterscotch and caramel in aroma.  Sticky sweet malt taste. Double type yeasty with light spice.  Ok.

750ml bottle from Country Club Liquors. Nose is candi sugar, golden raisins, with hints of bubblegum and clovey spices. Clear rusty brown with a big beige long lasting head. Flavor is lightly sweet with tinges of molasses and a very lightly bitter finish. Good but not great.
Bottle from Total Wine.  Mahogany color, smallish head.  Fruity aroma. Lots of plum and sweet cherry flavors, cinnamon and candied sugar.  A good US effort.  Solid.

bottle-dark mahogony with a small fizzy off-white head.  spicy phenolic nose of dark fruits (plums, red grapes) and spice (cinnamon).  mostly big dark fruit flaovrs here with some astringent notes of red grapes, plums and rasins.  lots of spice long into the finish-clove, cinnamon.  spritzy body to be expected for this beer.  finish is dark fruits and rasins.  decent beer but not great.  cool that SN did a true belgian beer for a change.  i hope the next one is a bit better-please brew a hoppy saison!!!

Color was a deep copper, almost chestnut brown.  Light head that didint last long.  Aroma of toffee, raisins, and earthy malt combined with some soft cocoa and soft coffee grounds.  Taste was not too complex nor exciting. The initial prickliness of the carbonation wore off after a few minutes, leaving a flattened beer.  Flavor had notes of toffee, candied sugar, soft cocoa and soft earthy tones. Typical dubbel, and I think, average for the style.
bottle at papsoe tasting. cloudy amber, small white head. aroma is spicy, malty, faint bitter from the alc. flavor is bitter caramelly, sweet fruity ,malty.
Bottle at Papsøs - Thanks. Clear brown - offwhite head. Apples, caramel, cpicy, cloves, nutty, fruity, bitterness, high phenols, candy, yeasty, caramel, light citric.

THOUGHTS: Great dubbel. One of the best American examples Ive tried. It could pretty much pass for Belgian. A touch sweeter up front than a lot of trappist dubbels, but otherwise finished just as dry & complex. Will probably age nicely. Equal parts fruity, spicy and malty with an underlying yeastiness. Great tasting, well-crafted beer. Nice balance. Bonus point for excellent label.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a medium brown with red highlights and a small to average creamy and fizzy, cream-colored head that mostly diminished and left fair to good lacing.  The aroma had moderate to heavy caramel and dark candi sugar; slight nutty and toasted malts; hints of chocolate; heavy doughy, fruity and spicy yeast; raisin, maple syrup and clove. The initial flavor was somewhat to moderate sweet, somewhat bitter and moderately acidic; while the finish was moderately sweet and light to moderately acidic with an average to long duration. There was caramel, molasses, hints of chocolate, maple syrup, brown sugar, lots of yeast, spices, peppery, dark fruit, acidic, fruit, raisin, a little red wine, dark candi sugar, very yeasty, a little alcohol and dark cherry. The nearly medium body was a little syrupy, but watery syrupy, and then very dry with very fizzy carbonation and a dry and slightly alcoholic finish.

750ml bottle 6/18/11 (Binnys Downers Grove)-46° in Trappist Glass-Pours a murky orangish brown with a small tan head. Aroma of dried fruits, sweetness, malts, yeast, and sugars. Taste of the same with more sugars and yeast coming in on the back end. This medium to full bodied brew is well balanced and a pretty darn good American brewed Dubbel.

22 fl bottle. Pours hazy orange to brown with a small tan head. Aroma is phenolic and caramelish to dark malty. Fruity, yeasty and caramelish. Fruity and slight citric. Phenolic and dark malty into the finish.

Aroma is rather subdued.  Immediately after uncorking there was a slight cider character which gave way to nuttiness and a faint concord grape juice scent.  Big bubbly tan head which quickly falls to a film. Deep red/orange beer.  Vigorous bubble streams.  Flavor leans toward bitter but not so much as a typical SN product. Nice biscuit character comes through with a bit of pepperiness.  Overcarbonated even for an abbey.  Body could be a bit fuller.  Overall a very nice beer but Id still pick a Belgian if I wanted to enjoy an abbey style as they would seem to have a richer, more complex malt character.

Bottled. A dark amber beer with a lazing off-white head. The aroma has notes of spices, malt, and caramel. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, yeast, over ripe fruits, caramel, and phenols, leading to a dry phenolic finish.
Bottle at Papsø. Pours hazy dark amber with a medium steady off white head. The aroma is dark fruit, yeast and caramel. The flavour is light spices, caramel, dark fruit and some raisins.

Bottle 75 cl. Courtesy of blutt59. Pours a hazy amber with an off-white head that dissipates completely. Brown sugar and friendly Belgian yeast in the nose. Medium body, heavy carbonation, overripe fruit and brown sugars with friendly phenols. A little licorice. Very subdued bitterness. The heavy carbonation and the missing head deducts from the overall impression, but its not a bad tasting beer. 170611
while there is some good qualities in this beer, there are too many flaws  that I cant go unnoticed. there is a good tart that brings some sweet cola flavor. the beer has a weak palate. very nice.

The aroma is nothing but it does have spice, hops, and a touch of sour fruit. The appearance is deep hazy amber with a small head. The taste is better than the aroma but has all the same elements plus malt. The palate is smooth. Overall its good despite not having a good aroma.

Draft @ Trappeze Pub, Athens, GA. Pours a clear amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty spicy yeasty aroma. Fruity malty spicy yeasty caramel flavor. Has a fruity malty spicy yeasty caramel finish.

Draft at hopleaf.  Okay some people were dogging this one but I found it quite drinkable.  Now, very far from a great Belgian but really nails that mediocre Belgian quality very well.  Its authentically average Belgian beer.  Easy drinking for 7.5%, thin, disjointed, fruity, lack-luster.

Sampled on tap at 1702, Tucson; April 2011
The beer arrives from the tap with a pale, amber tinged, tan colored head that starts out about one-finger in height.  murky (not clarity, just adjective) amber color, light show clear brown amber hue.  aroma quite fruity with fig, prune and raisin eqasily noticed; amplified fruitiness goes beyond these notes even.  spicy clove aromatics and touch other phenolics towards end.  The spice notes end up being the more noticeable character in the nose over time, though the fruit still plays an important role.

light sweet, lots of fruit melds with big clove presence that boosts both fruit and percieved sweetness.  clove lingers on palate in a long finish, touches of cardamom and woody hints of nutmeg.  When paired with my pizza I notice notes that are peppery, warming alcohol notes, and spicy higher alcohols are accentuated.  Dark caramelize sugar notes add flavors of molasses, rum and a hint of butterscotch. A prickly carbonation adds to the texture and works well with the lightly viscous, sometimes chewy, though appropriately light body that this beer has.  A whole grain malt note adds caramelized brown bread crust flavors, toasted grain and a molasses wheat bread like flavor to this beer.

This is a good, if not great example of the style.  It is a style i have never really been wowed by though.  This beer is solid, even tasty and I am happy to be drinking this right now, but it just doesnt get me all that excited in the end.

Right off the bat pours  into a deep amber reddish color with a nice off white head that stuck around for a while. The first sip surprised me, it was alot dryer that expected but notes of clove and raisins were present just a little subdued. Quite easy to drink for the style. All in all a great Dubbel, enjoy!

750ml bottle in a Trappist glass.  Pours cloudy brown with a thick, lingering, cream-colored head.  Aroma of sweet malts, light notes of chocolate and dark fruits, Belgian yeast but not too spicy, and light hops.  Strong flavor of malt.  Average texture.  This is Sierra Nevadas first real attempt at a different beer style that I have tried, and it is pretty good.

We Americans are really creeping up on the Belgian category. This is a fine specimen that pour a beautiful dark coffee brown color with a lofty lingering head. Mild aromatics. Medium nectar with excellent carbonation. This is a solid example of the style.
sorry, wasnt blown away by this one...dont know if the label threw me off, but just middle of the road dubbel for me.

Draft at Sugar Maple.  Burgundy-brown, murky amber color.  Nutty, raisin aroma, sweet Belgian sugar tones.  Mellow mouthfeel, not much carbonation or bitterness.  Approaching watery, but a very authentic dark fruit taste.  Old school feel.  Mild, very drinkable for the style.  Raisiny, chocolate tones in the finish.

Red grape aroma, effervescent yeast funk. Salt and pepper. Sweet and sugary, but with a dark base. Touch of berry. Really pleasant. 

Appearance is flat, dull brown with a tinge of purple. Medium head. Thick and murky. 

The flavor is dominant dark berries; touch of black cherry, but more grapes, dates, prunes and raisins. Finish of a sweet red win or port. 

Palate is fizzy with a dry, yeasty finish. Prickly. Thick and filling. Sweetness of fruits, and dryness of yeast. Beautifully balanced. Sweet and dry, both. A fizzy port-style dubbel.

Bottle. Clear red pour with a huge beige head. Aroma of banana, clove, caramel, biscuity malt and dark fruit. Rich caramel flavor with slight Belgian esters along with sweet honey and dark fruit before an estery, semi-dry finish. Im not much of a fan of dubbels, but this one was pretty nice.

(750 ml bottle from Damons) Pours dark reddish amber with a finger or so of light yellowish-white head. Aroma is somewhat vinous, sweet with a bit of spice and yeast. Mouthfeel light, airy, soft, a little dry, a little fizzy. Really not much lacing to speak of. Flavor is lightly sweet and vinous with touches of peppery spice and yeast.

750 ml bottle, corked and caged.  Bottle opens with quite a "pop" but no gushing. Pours a deep, slightly murky copper, like an old penny, with a 2 finger off white head. Head dissapates quickly and leaves no lace. Aroma is rich with dark fruit and brown sugar. Taste is sweet, balanced nicely with spice. Full palate with active carbonation.

From a corked and caged bottle, this opened with a satisfying pop.  Poured a very dark copper with a big foamy beige head that left light lacing.  Nose of dark ripe fruits with some raisins and spices. Medium body and a sticky mourthfeel. The flavor is rich and dominated by the fruit.  Overall it was enjoyable and easy to drink.  a

Its dark. Plum tinted. The head is like an old sponge... dry. The aroma is stiff, sharp, raisin, spice. The taste is of a low key malt. Its really smooth but I find less flavorful than expected. This velvety creation is perhaps too easy to drink but not rewarding enough. Afterall I did just get off work and it is FOF so I deserve it.

Amber with decent, creamy, tan head / Mild nose of spun sugar and dry hops / Medium to full body, a touch watery, sweet and syrupy with some hop balance and fair finish / Flavors of spun sugar, dry hops, cloves, and cinnamon with citrus notes / Not very Belgian in character.  A mediocre effort from the usually reliable SN.

Draft at WOB (Land o Lakes).  Pours a dark ruby brown with a thin tan head.  Aroma of spices, Belgian yeast, and candied sugar.  Great flavor with caramel malt sweetness and clove spices.  Nice finish.  The 7.5% is well disguised.

Draught at Tylers.   Pours a light copper with a small off-white head.  Nose is some sweet fruity phenols, earth, light pepper.   Flavor is a little sweet at first, more yeasty phenols, some breadiness,  a little bitterness at the finish.  Very drinkable.

bottle.  chestnut brown. caramel/maple/caramelized candy sugar nose, somewhat dirty and phenolic.   gelatin syrupiness.  harsh banana and white pepper phenols.  candy sugar and caramel goopiness with cola sweetness.

750 ml bottle. Opens with a huge pop and pours clear deep amber with a small fizzy beige head. Aroma of dark dried fruit, sugar, spices and some musty earth. Flavor is sweet sugar and malt with a light yeasty sourness and a faint hop bitterness. Alcohol is well masked. Medium body with average carbonation and a soft, smooth mouth feel that finishes a bit dry. Pretty solid Dubbel, Id buy this every once in a while.

750ml from Whole Foods, Raleigh. Digging this new series from SN, another example of old school U.S. micros spreading their wings of late. This is a style Ive cooled on in recent years, but I found this rendition pretty appealing. Part of this is due to the bright components of both the nose and the flavors. While the slightly cloudy brown pour didnt particularly inspire, the nose had a lot of promise, with more than the customary yeast-n-sugar nose of American dubbels. There was a light sourdough and spice element in there that appealed. Body was full and fairly smooth. Flavors were satisfying, bready and sweet for sure but with a grainy pumpernickel and fruit base that gave it some character. I dug it, and looking forward to the saison.

brownish amber pour with a thick off white head.
aroma is sweet toffee and cherry fruitiness. that belgian candy like yeastiness. 
flavour is dark fruit plum/cherry with a sweet rum cake maltiness. Light spicy alc develops as it warms.

Tasted on 4/18/11 on draft at Hopleaf.  Pours fiery amber with a thick beige head that slowly recedes to a rocky blanket of lace.  The nose is brown sugar, caramel, cocoa powder, light banana, and yeasty spices.  The flavor is similar to the nose with brown sugar, caramel, banana, prune, and a hint of bitterness.  The body is medium with lively carbonation and a long, spicy yeast, caramel, and prune finish.
Bottle. Pours amber/brown. Aroma of pear and caramelised sugars. Flavour of caramelised sugar, Belgian yeast and dark fruit. Quite dry aftertaste, a little too dry for my taste, but still good.

Pours a murky, dark rosy brown with a head that fizzles out quickly, leaving behind a still-looking beer. Smell is white pepper, yeast, pumpernickel bread, raisins, and a bit of black cherry. The taste is more fruity and candi sugar, which sweetens the bready yeastiness and makes it taste more like a Christmas spice cake. Once I swirled the yeast around and poured the dregs in, however, the white pepper really came back. So apparently Ovila yeast = pepper. That lends a little sharpness to it that could be mistaken for booziness, but that thankfully resides and becomes more warning than anything else. Its a little thin in the mouth, and the carbonation bites a little hard in the middle. All in all, this is decent, but the thinness is what stops me from loving this beer.
750mL bottle, pours dark copper. Aroma of candied sugar, sort of stale malts and caramel. Flavour of caramelized sugar, simple dark fruits and cloying sweetness. Disappointing.

I have to say I was interested to try this one given Sierra Nevadas epitomization of an American brewery and this being a Belgian style.  Pours dark rusty red-orange with two fingers of creamy dense head. Nose shows spiced and candied dark fruits and floral estery notes with hints of a caramelly sweetness. Nice dark fruit character in the flavor, raisins and spice cake with a mild rummy character. Yeast character kept well in check. Dry and light bodied with a mild spice on the finish.
Cola colored, sweet with dried fruits and a hint of chocolate, no head and just a little lacing, good but not great for a double.
Pours a dark amber color with an off-white head.  Aroma is of dark fruits, candied sugar, and belgian yeast.  Flavor is similar with plenty of the belgian yeast, candied sugar, and dark fruits.

750mL bottle.  Poured ruddy medium brown with an easily-resuscitated dirty beige head.. looked good when resuscitated.  The aroma picked up raisins, honey, and dates, with some drawn caramel backing.. earth and peppery yeast made it very intriguing.. didnt come across as a big beer.. I very much enjoyed it.  The flavor found raisin, fig, and date sweetness throughout, with cloves, black pepper, and dry, dusty earth throughout.. dry spices coated the mouth and were slightly bitter after the swallow.. warmed the belly more than I thought it would.  Medium-bodied with more carbonation across the middle.. fell off the sides rather abruptly.. OK feel and flow.  This was easy-drinkin and approachable.. I could go through a lot of it.

750ml from Winooski.
Appearance : Deep amber with a small head.

Aroma : Nice candi sugar with light caramel and light hops. Nice spices.

Taste : Nice sugar with light hops and spices. Dry and spicy finish. Light herbal hops. Soft carbonation.

Overall : Nice dry finish with really nice sugar. Nice spices. Not bad but nothing special. Enjoyable finish. Avereage dubbel.

Hazy, dark copper beer with an off-white head. Aromas of faint sweets mixed with fresh dough. A very thick, "bready" beer. Tastes of caramel, toffee, biscuit, hints of dried fruits, and some bittersweet malts. A bit of chocolate mixed in as well. Extremely smooth and easy to drink. Sweet toffee finish, nice beer.
pours hazy dark red with a disappearing white head.  aroma is berries, yeast and alcohol.  taste is alcohol, caramel and overripe fruit.  finish is bitter and dry

Pours ruby red with off-white head.  Aroma is primarily of dark fruit and candi yeast.  Taste is very soft.  Dark fruits, raisin, and caramel.  Very light carbonation in the mouth, a bit thin.  Short dry finish, very easy to drink.  Would drink again.

Sampled on draft at Smokin Joes in Pittsburgh this beer poured a caramel-amber color with a large foamy orange-beige head that lingered and left good lacing. The aroma was tart mixed berries and sugar. The flavor was tart cherry, berries, table sugar and bread. The finish was long and tart with lingering berry, sugar and bread. Fairly full bodied. Not much like a dubbel but I liked it.

"750 ml corked and caged bottle poured into a Trappist glass at 48°.  Color is a deep murky brown with mellow carbonation and a thin tight off white head.  Aroma is malty with caramel and yeast.  Medium body with a light crisp mouth feel.  Flavor of brown sugar, toffee and dried fruit, then the yeast shows with a faint hint of banana and a gentle bitterness.  After taste comes off slightly dry with a clean feel as the fruit flavors dissipate quickly.  This is a very well done Dubble, much better then I thought it would be.  The guys at Sierra Nevada are hop heads and I was afraid they would over hop this brew.  I look forward to the next two Ovila brews.

Clear reddish with thin off-white head in nice Oliva glass.  Sweet nose with a hint of Brett.  Musty, horseblanket, malty with follow-up of hops.  Very interesting.  Its a belgian dubble but nothing I can really compare it to because of this Brett undertone, although very slight, but it works.  Something appropriate for a long casual night.  Strikes me more like a Belgian brown (milder perhaps) with that slight sour slant.  Very interesting and unique. Quite surprising from SN.
Pours a brown color similar to the color of dirt.  Off white head.  Smells a bit of sugar and apples.  Tastes a bit like apples and brown sugar.

750 ml corked and caged bottle from Hayduke.  Lots of pressure behind the cork and it opened with a big pop.  A big fluffy tan head that slowly fades sits atop a medium brown hazy beer.  A rich malty nose with chocolate and light fruit.  Flavor is also rich and malty.  Chocolate, yeast, brown sugar, subtle fruit, and light nut flavors.  This is a solid Dubbel.

Bottle. Pours walnut brown, medium off-white head, spotty lacing. Nose is dark fruit, some candy, smoke and leather. Flavours of black walnuts, earth, candied dark fruit, smoke. Really nicely balanced. Great stuff!

poured from the bomber into a shaker glass. Aroma is malty, flavor is also malty and sweet, with hints of caramel and toffee. Almost like bellhaven, but much better. Overall a really good dubbel from sierra nevada.

From a 750ml into a wine glass.  Pours with a few inches of fizzy head.  Light Belgian and sweet aroma.  Very light and watery mouthfeel with lots of carbonation.  Taste was ech.  Like a half bottle of dubbel mixed with a half bottle of water.  It was downright bad.  I had a half a bottle and it wasnt even worth drinking.  Dont know if this was a bad bottle or what, but this was actually one of the worst dubbels (and beers) that Ive had.  Totally lacking in flavor.  Avoid!

Simple aromas, golden brown in color, with minimal head and some lacing along the glass.  Medium sweetness - with good carbonation, some candied sugars - but nothing overpowering.  This is a very drinkable brew with a clean finish ... need to get another one!
Bottle pours red/amber with an off-white head.  Aroma shows notes of toffee, fig, raisin bread, leather and yeast.  Flavor shows the same with additional notes of brown sugar, banana, and clove.

cola brown with a rejuvenating fine, tan head.  Aroma is a refreshing, naked yeast which suggested that the brew would taste boozy and thin for a dubbel.  It was.  Dryer than most dubbels, boozy, still refreshing, a slight dry maltiness in the finish, like a malty marzen with yeastiness added.  ok.
Tap. Light body. Subtle belgian yeast aroma/taste. Clear amber. Some caramel.

From bottle at Pints for Pets. Light caramel notes with a bit of hop character. Kind of plain. Medium dark amber body with foamy-creamy lacing off-white head. Medium-heavy body with mild alcohol warming and medium carbonation. Starts and stays sweet with caramel and sugar, mild fruity esters and alcohol warming. Little hop character, finishing sweet and smooth with some nutty bitterness. A bit of carbonic acidity. Finishes with just a bit of chalky hop resin.
Okay dubbel with a slight raison undertone along with a brown sugar like flavor in a body that seems somewhat wet by trappist standards.
Draft at blind tiger with Linh, Vi, and Thi. Pours a deep, gazy copper red body with no head. Aroma is spicy Belgian sweetness. Mouthfeel is plain, with notes of Belgian candy.

750ml bottle - $9.99 at Olde Crabapple Bottle Shoppe in Alpharetta, Georgia.

Very nice packaging involved, very sweet story and all, but lets see how the beer is.

Appearance: Pours a dark amber-brown body with just a hint of haze to it. Lofty, gassy, beige head. Though it thins out, the head manages to stick around for the entire undertaking.

Smell: Warming, swirling, shouting -- nothing seems to ever get this aroma off the ground. Just be quiet and happy with your indistinct, mild notes of dark bread, dark nuts, finely-ground spice, and a faroff sniff of cherry-flavor cough syrup.

Taste: Modest breadiness, then a quick drop-off into sugared sweetness and juicy fruitiness, with tastes of sweet cherries, raspberries, Anjou pears and prunes. Pinches of brown sugar and ground pepper up next. Slight toasted almonds, then a few cloves, which slides into a faint medicinal phenolic tone. And just when youre perceiving that faint medicinal phenolic tone, it subtly slides back towards the lightly tart berries, imparting some alcohol warmth. Drying, fruity finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-plus body. Medium-high, lively carbonation.

Overall: Ovila: Part One is neither awe-inspiring nor great, but its fairly good, though definitely falling short of the better brews Belgian (or the Belgian-inspired) has to offer.

Bottle from E street liquor: Poured a dark caramel brown color and created a short lived fizzy layer of foam that dissipated leaving the liquid naked without head. As for the aroma, my nose detects a fruity, sweet, and spicy scents attributed to authentic Belgian yeast thats wins me over; yet it is too subtle and would earn a higher aroma score if it were stronger. The flavor is sweet with a balanced caramel malt profile that is in perfect harmony with a spicy blend of yeast that isnt very overpowering but has enough spicing that it keeps my interest. I felt the price was a little to steep, but since it was a collaboration between Californian and Belgian brewers, I guess the price is justified.
Draft. Pours deep amber with an off white head. Lightly sweet malty aroma with yeasty spicy notes. The flavor is sweet and spicy. with yeast, clove, and dark fruits. Good stuff.
Bottle. Pours brown. Off white head. Nose/taste of dark fruits, brown sugar, fig, alcohol, spicy hops and yeast. Medium body. Smooth.

Mahogany reddish in color... Aroma is yeasty, candi sugar and caramel malts... Flavor is maltier, and less sweet than I would have expected... Fairly nutty with notes of citrus, belgian yeast apparent..... Pretty good...
Pours ruby with a khaki head. Aroma is sweet, doughy malt, Belgian spice. Flavor is sweet malt, light clove, yeasty, caramel, light spice.

Brown pour with attractively lively off-white head.  Fairly substantial effervesence and beading.  Nice complexity of aromas...sweet roasted malt, dark fruit, Belgian fruity yeast.   Flavors are likewise sweet, raisiny, clove, roasted caramel malt, bready, fruity yeastiness, black peppery finish.  Strong carbonation lends a lively palate and refreshes. A  really excellent version of the style!

On tap at Lunar Brewing Co., and dispensed to a snifter with a brown/amber, ruby highlighted hue, modest, off white head foam that quickly reduced to a ring & film, and left some light dots & dashes of lacing. The aroma was dark cherry/grape, almost vinous, a touch of funky yeast, smooth malt, and a little spice. The flavor added some warming alcohol, low hop bitterness, slight tartness, and good effervescence to the carbonation, in this flavorful, medium+ bodied brew.

Pours cola brown color with light tan head. Aromas of candy sugar, dark fruits, Belgian yeast and bread dough. Sweet raisin and Belgian yeast flavors with some spices and brown sugar. Medium body with moderate carbonation.

Medium brown pour with a nose of brown sugar, Belgian spices and yeast.

 A nice full body taste with flavors of spice, clove, caramel malts, banana 
and sugar. Very well blended.

Draft at copper mine.  Pours a murky bruin body with an off white head good retention and lacing up front.  Aromatically spicy and malty.  Dark fruit tones, raisins, cane sugar, and a hint of toffee.  Light yeast toned spiced esters with a spritz y hint of pepper.  Medium body soft carbonation.  Its a good interpretation but still feels quite short of a Belgian, especially a Trappist dubbel.  Just my opinion.
Bottle. Brune pour with tan head. Slight yeast, some fruit, some spices and light sweetness. Although there are many flavors, still comes across as almost bland. Body is light but nice,

Meh...I really wanted to like this to the point that I thought I couldnt be subjective. I love Sierra Nevada and I like dubbels. This was not that great. Aroma was very nice. Alcohol,dark fruit, yeast and a hint of spiciness. Pour was a clear ark brown with a one finger tan head. Taste was disappointing considering the nice aroma. Brown sugar, raisin and Belgian yeast. Very thin mouth feel and turns to water before the swallow. Very light carbonation (near flat) which is not what I expect for the style. Not much aftertaste. Boring beer.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottle @ Blind Pig. Medium hazy brown. Really hard to tease out the aroma, even after lots of air time. Raisins, caramel, spices. Somehow this beer is best defined as vague. Okay I guess, but definitely not worth the price I paid. Pretty forgettable really.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Sierra Nevada did a nice job with this one. Great balance and finish. Very smooth and easy to drink. i found it to be a very pleasant drink and a good example of a Dubbel.

Tap. Cloudy, dark muddy brown with not much head. Toasty, nutty, and faily malty and dry aroma. Not too sweet, but touch of fig slides, nutty, and toffee in the finish. Pretty average actually, but nothing off. Thinner body with bubbly carbonation.

Location: 750 ml bottle shared by NickD717 to begin a certain celebratory weekend, 4/8/11


Aroma: The nose is yeast, spice, some toffee, caramel, fig and other dark fruity notes

Appearance: The pour into the hotel glass was medium brown with a lasting tan head

Flavor: The taste is mid-heavy sweet, with lots of malty flavors, fruity notes, and spice

Palate: The body is medium (leaning full), with average carbonation, and a solid mouthfeel

Overall Impression: 
Overall, this was a fairly interesting attempt at a Belgian style from SN, and one that I enjoyed.  I had a decent amount of complexity to it as well.  Thanks for cracking this one open and sharing it Nick!  A good way to start off the weekends festivities.

shared 750ml bottle.  deep cloudy red / light brown color with a small off white head.  spicy, yeast driven nose with layers of dark fruit including raisin and red grapes.  medium body with solid carbonation, sweet malts up front, dark fruits throughout and a touch of pepper / spice on the top and back.  sweet dry finish with more raisin notes along with a touch of banana and bubblegum.  the yeast shines through on this one.

The beer pours a hazy brown color with a tan head. The aroma is a mix of Belgian yeast, toffee and candy sugar. I dont have any complaints from the aroma, which smells like a dubbel should smell. The flavor a nice mix of toffee, yeast and candy sugar. The alcohol is detectable but is not overpowering. The beer is very smooth and easy to drink. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. One of the best American-made dubbels that I have tried.

Ruby red in color. Cloudy in appearance with a creamy, thick white head. The lacing coats the side of the glass. The aroma has cherry and wheat but it also consist of a sour grenn apple jollyrancher. Cherry and wheat notes are in the flavor. Light sweet flavor that dissappears into a spicey note. The texture of this beer gives your mouth a dry, sticky feeling. The finish is smooth but does not excite the palate. I am glad i was told to try this beer. It was well worth it.

750 ml cork and caged bottle from Spirits Brick. Ppured a slight reddish dark brown underneath a larger slighlty off white dense creamy head. Aroma is fruity and earthy with notes of raisin, fig, dirt, prune, plums and definitely gets better with warmth. Palate is fuller mouthfeel with slightly stronger carbonation and an almost light dry finish. Flavor of grains, light dark fruit, prunes, plums, dates, sour raisins and slight coccoa. Solid beer that needs to be drank on the warmer side of things to be enjoyed.

750 bottle thanks to me. Pours hazy brown with a small white head.  Nose of candi sugar, bubblegum, background spiciness. Taste starts off with some sugary sweetness, leading to some cloying and a strange tartness/sharpness at the end. Maybe its the carbonation that leaves a tingling on my tongue. Almost taste like a Dr. Pepper with bubblegum and cough syrup on the end. This is very difficult to style to hit dead on and SN doesnt get close on this one-very disappointing.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: 750ml bottle from a BT trade. shared with jsprime and jeff lewis. very malty dubble. not as complex as i was expecting. perhaps suffered from following zuur. would happily have again.

I agree that this is one of the best American brewer takes on the Abbey Dubbel style.  The excellent balance is what really strikes me.  Pours a deep amber, brown color with an off-white foam head.  Lots of life in it.  Has an aroma of caramel, dark fruit, pepper, and a subtle hint of clove from the belgian yeast.  Candy sweet start with notes of caramel and pepper, with a nice layer of dark fruit and clove underneath.  Sugary sweet finish.  Thin to medium mouthfeel.  For me the subtle pepper spice gives this brew a nice balance where some dubbels are all sugar and yeast.

The rare Sierra Nevada Belgian styles that I have tried previously were competent, but didnt blow me away.  I think, however, they have turned a corner with this one.  Deep copper, beautiful lasting pillowy head.  Aroma was caramel, hint of toffee, and apricots and prune fruitiness.  Flavor was essentially a match, although the prune fell back and dates and figs came forward.  Fruity, mild spicy phenols.  I would have like a touch more body, but cant complain.  One of the better American takes on this style ever done IMHO.  Cant wait to try the rest of this series.  Nice to see someone other than Ommegang and Allagash cranking out a good version of this style.

Medium brown pour, off-white head.  Caramel and brown sugar aroma with banana and a little spice.  Toasty bread and caramel body with banana, date, and apricot in the middle, a little spice as it finishes.  Feels a bit thin bodied for the style.

Bottle. Pours a dark burnt amber orange with an off-white head that dissipated to the edges. Aroma is full of sweet bread with some dark fruits, caramel and a bit of candied sugar. Flavor was similar with some dark fruits and raisins in the start with some spice and growing sweet bread notes.
Draft at RNH. Deep brown color, toffee smell, roasted nuts and honey. Very malty taste. Almost like a brown ale, Didnt really do much for me.

Draft Mostly clear, burnt orange ale with a small, short-lived, white head. The bouquet furnishes candied nuts, crusted port, a little chocolate and a touch of gooey caramel. Medium-bodied with tingly carbonation. The flavor offers caramel and toffee sweetness intermingled with moderate bitterness and a splash of medium sherry. Finishes minerally and very lightly bitter. Not much in the way of the typical Belgian esters and phenols that usually rub me the wrong way.

I poured a 750ml bottle into an oversize wine glass.Appearance: Pretty shade of dark orange/brick red. Very hazy, but noticeable amount of carbonation. Forms a large, yellow, frothy head which retains and regenerates well, but doesnt lace the glass.Smell: Very mild nose with plum, fig, tobacco and general barley scent. Taste: Sierra Nevada is known for making bold beers and this is based on a traditional Belgian Trappist dubbel style, so why is this palate so darn mild? I went into this beer with my palate braced for shock, but was touched with a mild, malty, slightly fruit brew. Just like the aroma the palate is a dark fruit basket of plum, cherry, fig, red apple - all with a sweet caramel backbone. Ordinarily, this would be the description of an excellent beer, but in the case of Ovila its extremely mild. It has the complexity of an orchestra, but the volume of a transistor radio. Composition has a lot to do with the palate as well, as its an extremely fizzy beer for the style and the texture is noticeable thin and maybe even a tad oily. Theres really nothing overtly astringent, sour, tangy or otherwise foul here, and I wouldnt considered it a bad beer at all. That being said, its lacking the robustness it needs to work as anything other than an okay beer.Mouthfeel: Surprisingly fizzy and foamy. The head expands as it enters the mouth. The liquid seems thin for what should be at least a medium bodied brew. Drinkabilty: By far the most quaffable Belgian dubbel on the market. However, beers of this style arent meant to be slugged down as if they were fizzy yellow lagers. Sure, its nice it goes down so easily and is drinker-friendly, but more energy and spice is needed. Then 7.5% ABV is well hidden with zero alcohol presence in the aroma, taste, or constitution. A good beer to pair with cheesecake.Overall, a magnificent failure of a beer. Something that is genuinely difficult to dislike, but equally difficult to cheerlead for. It garners a thumbs up from me, but just barely.
Pretty good for Sierra Nevada but in no way compares to great a Dubbel like Allagash.

750Ml bottle, caged & corked.  Chestnut color, light tan head.  Aroma of toasted nuts, caramelized malts, and dried dark fruits.  Mostly nuts.  Flavors include tobacco, nuts, caramel and toffee, some dry date flavors, dark bread, roasted barley.  Finishes with a chalky dry texture.  This is by far the BEST Sierra Nevada beer Ive had.  Complex, fulfilling, excitingly flavorful, and not to be too clique... spiritual.  

7,5,10,5,18

Pours dark and ruddy with a creamy head that lasts throughout.  Smells of burnt caramel as it pours.  As it sits, deep rich fruity aromas develop like raisins, grapes, and dates.  A slight earthiness comes in.  Strong and bold fruity flavors of rich dark fruits, caramel, a touch of spice on the tongue, and baked yeast.  The finish is long and rich, a touch of spice as well.

Bottle. Mahogony beer with a nice big cream colored head. Malt and caramel aroma with yeast. Malt and caramel flavor with yeast and light spice. Medium bodied. Malt and caramel lingers with yeast and spice.
Pours a reddish brown color with a large foamy canvas head. Notes of brown sugar, cloves, and some raisins. Mouthfeel is kind of weak and finish is on the shorter side. i was expecting more.

Bottle; cloudy brown with medium tan head; aroma-dried fruits,spices...milder than most dubbel; taste-light, mild sweetness, little tart, mild bitterness and carbonation. Good attempt but I would rather a heavier fruit taste.

Bottle from 2 Stones beer pub in Newark DE...  Pours a murkey brown color, decent head.... Nice aroma of some brown sugar, malts, dark fruits. Taste is classic abbey dubbel style. Fruity, dark raisons, figs, malt base, light brown sugar, but not sweet. Yeasty taste.... Medium body, on the creamy side. Overall. Nice dubbel!
Bomber. Pours dark amber with a nice quarter inch cream head that retains. Aroma is dark fruit. Flavor is dark fruit and caramel. Very nice dubbel.

750ml bottle. Pours a clear, deep ruby-copper-amber-orange colored body with a finger-width, dense and frothy, light tan head that dissipates slowly and leaves a veil of lacing throughout. Aroma is really nice. Yeasty and spicy up front with some dark fruits and esters alongside. Malts arent plump, but work really well and offer some medium sweet caramels and a touch of bready toast. Plums, raisins, candi sugar, banana, and a light peppery clove. The pepper definitely comes out nicely as this warms more. Flavor is a bit more malt forward, but still pleasantly yeasty and spicy with a nice dark fruitiness. Caramel, plums, raisins, and some toast up front before some banana esters and phenols come in. Yeasty spice, clove, and a light pepper kick up towards the end along with a bit more of a breadiness. Candi sugar comes out in the finish as well while this dries completely, but it seems a bit thin with no real hop bitterness. The yeasty spices easily balance the bready caramels and smooth finish before leaving a fairly lengthy aftertaste. Medium body and a fairly creamy, higher carbonation. Overall, a nice dubbel. Well balanced with a nice yeasty spiciness, dark fruits, and lighter bready caramel. A bit thin in the finish, but the peppery yeast made up for it nicely. Solid beer.

750ml bottle. Rating #162. Lightly hazed dark brown/amber with a nice dark white head. Nice sweet toasted malt aroma, nice little brown sugar thing going on as well. Lightly swee sugar and more toasted (very light) malts, very easy to drink, good stuff. (1701)
