text: On tap at Sugar Maple.  Ruby red with a thin off-white head.  Aroma of fruit, caramel yeast and toasted malt.  Taste is fruity with toasted malt, yeast, sugar and light spice.  A touch thin and finishes up dry and yeasty.

Deep amber pour good layer of light creamy beige head good retention  ... aroma of dark overripe fruits and fruity yeast, sweet malts and a little spice ... taste is of dark fruits, caramel malts, chocolate and fruity yeast with a light bite of spice ... a smooth and creamy mouthfeel with rich flavors a great solid dubbel

On tap at Papago in Phoenix pouring up a nice looking ruby red amber with off white head. The mild aroma emits some roasted malts, some fruity esters (blueberry maybe) and then a thin layer of chocolate syrup drizzled earthiness. The taste is up front prunes, dried cherries and raisins. Toward midway it picks up a touch of dryness from roasted malts. It seems to come together nicely into the finish with the addition of some cold earthiness. Cool brew.

750mL, no date.  $10.99 at Bowery Whole Foods.  Clear copper brown with a 1 1/2 finger light beige head, creamy with fair to good retention.  Fruity yeasty esters up front, some chocolate notes followed by a fair amount of spice, raisins, and toasted malt..  Spicy clove phenols in the flavor dominate with the chocolate and toasted malt, light candi and brown sugar.  Flavor is still raisiny and figgy, some white pepper added along with a little vanilla.  The finish is dry, with bitterness at a 2.  Medium body with high carbonation.  Drier than Im used to for a dubbel (with less candi sugar), with more toast than Im used to as well.  Still, a solid effort for sure.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: UPDATED: JUL 30, 2011 rich brown pour.  a very smooth dubbel malty sweet aroma and flavor but subdued and a very nice beer

Appearance:   dark reddish/brown, with orange notes; thick, creamy one-finger light tan head; tons of silky, tiny-bubbled lace curtains	.   Aroma: notes of caramelized brown sugar, raisins, graham crackers, clove, hint of banana.   Taste: ginger snaps, molasses, brown sugar, toasted bread, clove, a little peppery spice, a hint of old leather and maybe some cherry pie filling.   Finish: a little sweet, with a pleasantly soft zing of spices giving way to a bit of tobacco.   Notes: Absolutely wonderful.  Might be the very best American version of an abbey dubbel Ive ever had.  To me, this beer is just a notch below the Chimay Red.

Brown with white head.  Aromatic caramel and musty hop aroma.  Sweety and malty.  Notes of brown sugar, caramel, dough, cherry, cinnamon and cereal grains.  Also a bit of yeast and some balancing hops.  Its sweet but not cloying.  Description on bottles notes black pepper and clove...ehh, maybe a little.  I love dubbels and this is a good one.  Smooth and drinkable.

Serving: 750 ml. bottle from Wegmans Leesburg.  It pours a dark reddish brown with a foamy tan head that fades very quickly.  The nose is of dried fruit, fig, and date.  The flavor has some dried fruit notes and an off metallic note.  Raisin and fig but no yeast notes, a bit on the flat side.  Medium bodied with a lesser amount of rather large bits of carbonation leading to an unremarkable finish.  This one tastes rather underdeveloped.  No depth of flavor, no yeast, no fine carbonation.  Rather disappointing.

Raisin and gym sock aroma. Hazy ochre, medium yellow head. Raisin flavor which transforms into maraschino cherries in the end. The combination of the two at midpalate is superb. Well made, straightforward dubbel.

On draft at Brass Tap Wesley Chapel.  Pours a dark brown with an off-white head.  Nose is caramel, esters, banana, brown sugar, and some toffee.  Flavor is similar with the caramel, brown sugar, and banana up front and the yeast esters in the back (some slight banana all over flavor profile).  Light-bodied and an interesting take on a Belgian Dubbel.

A: The pour is a somewhat opaque amber color with a finger of khaki colored head.

S: Sweet malt and bread up front with a nice bit of caramel.  There is some sweet sugar, especially brown sugar, and quite a lot of dark fruits.  Currants and raisins are the primary fruits, but there is plenty of banana and a moderate spiciness.

T: Great maltiness to this beer.  Bread gives great substance to it and theres of course caramel and dark fruits.  Banana and clove contributions from the yeast and there are some hints of alcohol from time to time.

M: Medium in body with a smooth, creamy carbonation.

O: Glad Sierra Nevada has redeemed after the miss that was Hoptimum.  Solid stuff.

Pours a cloudy brown with a disappearing tan head.  Delicious aroma of brown sugar, dark fruit, and some green apple and clove.  Sweet bready flavor with fruit, caramel, spices and some yeast.  Creamy mouthfeel with a yeasty finish.  Overall, one of the better American-brewed Abbey ales.

20110427  750ml bottle from Honeygo.  Clouded but glowing dark amber with creamy, tall beige head.  Aroma is full of ripe, rotting fruity phenols, banana bread, walnut, caramel.  Smells sweeter than I expected, and thats okay, just a surprise.  Body is creamy and full, perhaps a bit too much so for my taste, but its fine.  Medium sweetness, very mild bitterness, slight peppery yeast.  Yeasty burps and retronasal booziness. Wish I had cracked this one to share, because the full bottle is a bore.
Bottle pours a murky brown/copper with a thin off white head. Scent is caramel, fruit and yeast. Taste is fruity, spicy and yeasty.

Corked bottle from H.E.B.Pours a deep, rich amber/mahogany with nice lacing and a thick off-white head.  Aroma is slightly coppery malt with hints of hops, bread, and plumb.  Flavor is sweet bread, sugary pepper, candy malt, and lightly toasted plumb bread.  Nice mouthfeel  Not a bad dubbel but not the best.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Typical dubbel pour with a sparkling mahogany color and an average, beige, fizzy head which is mostly diminishing and leaves minimal lace.  The nose makes up for it; clovey and peppery phenols, some brown sugar, golden raisins, molasses, a little toasty, and earthy.  The flavor lacks a bit of the malt and yeasty richness; some light brown sugar, an earthy presence, light clove, toasted caramel, and faint raisin and pepper.  The palate is less than lively, watery, more than medium, but slightly silky.  The beer finishes similarly with brown sugar, a light to moderate acidity, some raisin, and toasted caramel with a peppery warmth.  Actually quite similar to the style but just lacks richness and body to back it up.

Pours brown with a thin white head. aroma is very nice strong and malty with notes of vannilla and belgian yeast. Flavour is very nice bold fruity and complex. an excellent brew, It has it in  all the places i want it.

Smells very much like a trappist ale; dried fruits and very sweet malts. Good head on pour and great lacing. Cloudy and brownish, looks pretty trappisty too. Much more subtle tasting than the trappists, its still sweet and  cloudy on the tounge.  Nice trappist representation, lacking in %, sweet heaviness and a long fruity palate.
Pours copper red. The aroma has plum, raisin a spicy note. The flavor has plum, raspberry, cherry, leather and star anise. Nice.

750 ml. bottle. Served at cellar temperature. Pours a fluffy, light beige head, over a very slightly hazy, amber (SRM 15) body.....nose is heavy with malt aromas, including, toffee/caramel, raisin, plum and a bit of cocoa....taste is light sweet malts to start, leading to dried fruits including raisin, plum, finishing with light clove, and a light pepper bite....mouth feel is light, sticky, carbonation high. Malty sweetness dominates this beer. There are some balancing fruit and spice tones but sweet prevails. This is not as big, nor as complex as the best in this style.  BJCP 8/3/14/4/6
750 mL bottle in a snifter.  Medium brown pour with moderate tan head.  Caramel aroma.  Malty flavors with hints of fruit and spice.  Mildly bitter finish.  Very well balanced.  Nice mouth feel.

Cloudy brown, modest foamy head. Initial reaction wasnt exactly positive. Overly raisiny and phenolic, seemed one dimensional and not subtle or complex enough. But I set in drinking this along side my Easter dinner of prime rib and it turned into a fairly bang-on accompaniment. It doesnt stand along with the Trappistes, but it did grow on me.

Slightly khaki head, with a dark brown body.  Maybe slightly lighter than dark brown.  Powdery coat looking almost.  Small bubble carbonation.  Smell is yeasty, with plenty of raisins and some spice.  Almost like you would want to marinade your meat with it.  Fresh tasting which makes it refreshing as compared to other dubbels.  Taste is brown, floral, slightly sweet.  Ending is slightly carbonated, dry, chemic.  True to the style, nice palate.  As good as any other world class dubbel ale.

Bottle from kegs and barrels.  This beer pours a deep reddish/amber with a thin off white head.  The aromas are raisins, dates, plums.  The mouthfeel is sticky and slightly sweet with a medium body.  This was a very nice beer.  Cheers!

Unique beer. Has a brown but somewhat cloudy look in the glass. Aroma has some raisins and a little spice to it. Taste has a definite prune and some plum tastes. Not used to this style of beer but I think it could grow on me. Nice finish.

I might have liked it more if the bartender didnt fill the glass up with foam and gave it to me before it settled. So this is only an account of 60% of an Ovila. It pours like liquid prunes with a massive white head. the aroma has a lot of funky bread and spice notes. It tastes like a typical belgian strong ale but it kind of lays limp on the tongue and washes out very quickly. Its not an unpleasant taste but hard to distinguish from all the other dubbels Ive ever had.

Bottle shared by ewestern.  
Whoa... an impressive Dubbel.  How the hell is this brewed by Sierra Nevada?  Extremely well-balanced and everything comes together exactly how it should.  The best American made Dubbel in my opinion.  Fruity, yeasty, caramel and dark Belgian candied sugar.  Sweet flavor that ends moderately dry.  The palate is nice with soft, lively carbonation.  Well done.
Tap @ Falling Rock.  Deep amber pour with thin lasting head.  Light aroma of clove, pepper, yeast and raisin.  Light, dry mouth.  Long lasting fig despite thinness in body.  Tobacco, caramel malts.
This beer is nice, but not really spectacular. Quite sweet, there seems to be something about dubbels that just isnt there for me. Good once, but not a repeat buy at the price.
Copper pour with thin off white head. Aroma burnt biscuits and malts. Taste is yeasty with some spice. Good body. Enjoyable beer.

As usual, SN hits it out of the park.   This is the part of my review where I get lazy and just start clicking the "beer rating assistance" words to describe this beer (which I liked very much):  caramel, nuts, toast, roasty, resin, herbs, earthy, dough, banana, butterscotch, raisin, vanilla.

Bottle to tulip. Dark copper pour with a creamy frothy kahki head that lasts. Aroma is bread and some sweet faint fruit and brown sugar. Taste is watery, but pleasant with some dark fruit and sugar with a bread like texture and spice. Palate is thin and very fizzy with a gritty chaulky dry finish.

on tap at redlight. pours a medium murky brown with a nice frothy white head. the nose is nutty, fruity, raisins, and a bit of caramel. taste is mild fruits, sweet maltyness, and belgian yeast. nice full body, really drinkable. overall a pretty good beer, it surprised me.

Bottle:  The aroma consists of consists figs, grape bubblegum, caramel, raisin, and Belgian yeast.  It pours a cloudy orangish-brown with a two finger khaki head that last a minute or so before fading to a thin film outlined by a thick ring around the edges of the glass.  The flavor starts with figs, caramel, and a Belgian yeastiness that reminds me of Unibroue, but a more mild version of Unibroue yeastiness.  The finish has clove, faint grape bubblegum,  and raisin.  Medium bodied with moderate-lively carbonation.

Poured from a bottle at the special session at Extreme Beer Fest. Apparently the world premiere.

Pours a medium chestnut brown with a light tan head. Nose brings some mild nuttiness and some dark fruits--raisins and a bit of date character. Mild caramel and bread in the background. Flavor is stronger with good fruit and sweetness plus some malt. Well rounded. Body is medium with light to moderate carbonation. Drinkability is nice. Good story and a pretty good beer.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-12-2011

Excited to try this beer. Aroma is full of raisin and belgian yeast. The appearance is a darker brown/red color. The taste is very obviously a belgian yeast beer, but the remaining ingredients used separate this beer from the others. It has a very clean finish and the flavor has enough sweetness to balance the yeast. Overall it is a good beer, but nothing amazing. I look forward to more beers from this series

750ml bottle from Binnys.  Im glad to see this made it out here as Ive wanted to try it for some time.  I pull off the cork and am greeted by a loud pop.  It pours reddish brown with a minimal white head, eventually settling into a white ring with some small clouds of bubbles floating about.  Aroma of belgian yeast esters, some raisin, a significant amount of brown sugar.  Some fruitiness as well.  Flavor has toffee, caramel, brown sugar with mild Belgian yeast esters.  There is a fair amount of spice: specifically clove and pepper.  Mild fruitiness.  Somewhat sweet, with a mild bitterness that comes mostly from the spicing.  Smooth mouthfeel with soft carbonation.  Finishes on a lingering caramel note.  This is really good for an American Dubbel.

750 ml corked and caged bottle poured a clear reddish brown with a lasting beige head. Aromas of carmel, brown sugar, pepper, light fruittiness and light spice. Palate was medium bodied and smootrh. Flavors of carmel, brown sugar and light spice with a smoth lingering carmel finish. I expected more, but this is fairly boring example of a Dubbel.

750 bottle. Pours cloudy brown/ruby, with moderate amount of well constructed off white head that dissipates slowly with lots of lacing.  Nose of banana, bread malt, and dried fruit.  Taste is bready, with notes of cherry, dried fruit, toffee backbone, and a mildly sweet finish. Not as much depth or complexity as a true belgian and lacking in some mouthfeel, but overall very good.

A - Pours a fairly cloudy amber-brown color with a big finger and a half of frothy off-white head. The head retention is very solid lacing nicely on the way down.

S - Aroma is full of sweet roasted caramel malts and dark fruits. There is also some yeast, banana, and spices mixed in as well.

T - Starts off with sweet roasted caramel malts and some light fruit flavors. I bit of spices and a touch of yeast in the background. Through the middle, some more spices and some banana come out in the middle. The finish is a mix of roasted flavors, some dark fruit (raisins), and some yeast flavor that lingers.

M - Medium bodied with moderate lively carbonation. Might be a touch over carbonated. Finish is fairly pleasant, with just a hint of alcohol warming. 

D - Very drinkable. Smooth and crisp and the flavors a pretty well balanced. Feels like it could have had a bit more flavor and a touch more depth, but overall, very tasty.

On tap at Brouwers. Pours a deep, reddish brown, with a smallish, foamy, off-white head. Mild cherries, fruit snacks, and some caramel on the nose. Nice, full flavor follows suit. Milder than something like a Westmalle, and not as juicy, but drinks very easily. No alcohol presence, and a lively carbonation keeps it from feeling sticky. Pleasant - but not great.
bottle, thanks to dixonian,  amber orange color with no foam, aroma is malty sweet belgian sugar, flavor is fruity with some smoke and a thin finish

750 ml bottle shared by John at The Royale; he and I both got bottles from Randalls. Thanks again, John! Pours a cloudy brown-amber color with an inch-thick, foamy beige head. Aroma of spicy grains, Belgian yeast, pepper, fruits, sweet and chocolaty malts. Flavor of caramel malts, candi sugar, herbs, pepper, and fruits. Medium-bodied, with soft, medium carbonation and a spicy, malty mouthfeel. Really cool, unique dubbel.
Just not very interesting. I guess I look for something in a beer to set it apart from what is average, and there just isnt anything here.

750 cc from Capones.  Pours turbid coppery ruby with big fluffy 3-finger head.  Nose is fruity, hoppy, with yeasty malty and spicy notes.  Good nose on this.  Tastes old aley, with rock sugary malt, dank cobwebby yeasty esters, fruit, and hops.  Complex palate, gets drier late, and comes off like a dry fruity old ale, but works pretty well holistically.
Pours orange copper with nice notes of citrus and pepper spices.  The mouth shows more of the malt and caramel with a very long spiced finish.
On tap at Pizza Port OB. Copper with off-white head. Nose raisins and cherries. Taste big full sweetness. Belgian yeast cherries malt and a sugar back. Lovely.

Bottle.  A dark brown murky color with a big foamy tan head.  A classic malty dubbel aroma that sweetens as it warms with some raisins and spices.  Dry and malty flavors with a light fruit (raisin) and touch of pepper.

4/18/11. 750mL bottle. Not clear, but not exactly hazy, deep brown/red pour with a big fluffy tan head that cuts in half but sticks very well. Dry Belgian yeast aroma with a hint of grapes and caramel. Caramel and grapes in the flavor with dry Belgian yeast and a touch of metal. Not bad!
Bready yeast aroma.  Flavor more subtle than expected, mildly malty with a hint of spiciness.
10oz pour @Fountainheads. Nice brown, murky appearance. Bready, yeasty, nice interpretation of a dubbel. A little thin for me, but a nice beer.

Draft at Capones.

Pours a deep, dark maroon/burgundy color with golden mahogany edges and a half finger off-white head that quickly settles into a thin lasting ring. Minimal spots of lacing.

Sweet malt aroma that is slightly spicy with hints of rye, caramel, dark fruit, pepper, cinnamon and candy sugar. Bready yeast in the nose with zesty clove as well as a slight cough syrup presence and dark fruit. Hints of plum, raisin and fig. Faint alcohol.

Medium bodied with a blast of zesty spice up front that lingers throughout over the sweet malt backbone and boozy heat into a dry finish. Hints of pepper, clove, brown sugar, cinnamon and candy sugar. Sweet vinous presence with hints of grape, plum, raisin and fig. Slight alcohol but the ABV is well masked and the beer is decently balanced. As it warms, the malts become more prominent but its very dry and spicy and could use some more complexity.

Bottle @ home. Cork opened with a huge pop and a chocolate nose. Brown appearance with a medium sized creamy tan head. Candy sugar, chocolate, dark Belgian malty nose with a hint of fruitiness and light booze. Creamy, carbonated, fairly thick dark Belgian malty flavor with hints of dark chocolate and light fruits (apples, pears). A touch spicy, but mostly just a sugary dark malty Belgian ale finish.

poured a slightly opaque brown hue with a light beige head.   The aroma was a mild disappointment it had some roasted malt notes and some caramel even a little bread but it was very mild nothing really profound.   Flavor was balanced between sweet and bread malts and finished with a nice yeasty note.  Some mild cloves in the finish. A nice beer that needed a little more spice to it.

on tap at Tylers Apex, 3/22/11. Good aroma, sweet, hints of yeasty spice, clove. Mild chocolate, dried fruits. Reddish brown color, Good head and lace. Sweet flavor, Lite body, smooth creamy mouthfeel, mild spice finish. Tasty, rich in flavor, yet easy to drink. I wonder if I liked it better because people at the bar said they didnt like it.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Pours a one-finger khaki head that fades quickly leaving some lace. Hazy amber color.  Good carbonation and medium bodied. Light malty, caramel nose and flavor is similar - not sweet caramel with hops staying in background. $10.99 for a 750ml caged & corked bottle from Kappys Liquors Peabody, MA.

750ml bottle.  Clear white head on top of a light yellow beer.   Sweet aroma and very first taste.  Thin bod with some carbonation.   Sticky mouth feel from all the caramel and fruit sweetness.  None of that musty Belgium funkiness.   Crisp and drinkable.

(draft @ Tap and Mallet - Rochester, NY) Dark brown pour with a very thin tan head. Sweet and sugary aroma with some light spice and yeast. Flavor is very sweet at the start. Lots of fruit and sugar with a raisin and yeast aftertaste. For as sweet as the flavor is, its very mild and disappears quickly. Ok but couldve been a lot better.

draft at Blue Monk, Buffalo. ruby brown color. sweet malts with hint of Belgian yeast. Some underlaying raisins & dark fruit. Flavor is sweet malts, caramelized sugar, touch of yeast. Decent flavor but it needs to be more concentrated IMO, needs some oomph to it.

Deep copper to brown color.  The wispy light tan head laces the glass.  Spicy nose with Belgian yeast, raisin, and dried fruit aromas.  Sweet malt flavor nicely balanced by hop bitterness.  Spicy fruit, raisin,dark fruit, caramel, and candy sugar notes.  Full bodied with a creamy mouthfeel.  Would definitely recommend trying this one.

Bottle. Poured clear dark brown color with an average light brown head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate to heavy caramel and yeast aroma. Medium body with smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium well balanced sweet fruit flavor with a medium complex sweet finish of moderate duration. Good brew.

750ml bottle. Poured a dark amber-brown color with a medium sized off-white head that dissipates to wisps soon afterward. Aroma is raisins, other dried fruits, caramel, yeast. Flavor is  dried fruits (raisins), yeast, caramel notes, touch of maple, spice. Body is surprisingly smooth, since Ive run into my fair share of dubbels that are heavy and hard to consume. I actually drank this entire 750 myself without a problem. Great.

750 ml. bottle- Pours what looks dark reddish brown but is ruby red when held up to the light, head is smaller than expected, reducing to a collar and a couple of islands of foam, lacework blankets the glass. The aroma is Belgian candy sugar and yeast, some banana, nice. The flavor is much mellower than the real thing, but has a deep complex body, sweet, sugary, banana esters and apple. Body is full, carbonation is high, finish is syrupy. Overall the true trappist dubbels are superior, but this is a nice first attempt at a Belgium beer, cant wait for the saison and the quad. Cheers!

Shes alright...  Smells and tastes like pure caramelized sugar and cinnamon.  This is a good example of a beer that really needs food to extenuate its excellence.  Im thinking barbecue pork or duck would go perfectly with this dubbel.

Bottle (finally getting around to rating this). Pours with a somewhat murky, effervescent copper to deep bronze body with a thick, tall, creamy, tan head of foam that stays for the duration and leaves pretty good lacing. Aromas of esters and phenols: clove, banana, pear, prunes, rum-raisin, candi sugar, spicy. Smells pretty dry. Perhaps a bit earthy and there is a light alcohol note. Malt aroma is far in the background compared to the yeast in the nose. Flavors are smooth and a bit more malt forward than in the nose: bready, toasty, complex. Some candi sugar notes in the finish. Raisins, rum and a bit more restraint of esters and phenols than on the nose. Dark fruits, clove and pepper. Rich nut well attenuated. Balance is found in dryness instead of by hops. Very dry. Long duration of flavors, dry finish. Creamy and high carbonation carries a medium body. Some warmth. Very dry.

This has a dark amber/brown color with a light brown head.  A yeasty sweet, almost candy-like, sticky aroma (thats actually kinda good).  The yeast carries through to the flavor, diminishing quickly with a malty sweet, almost sour, wash and nearly no finish other than a lightly soured malt.  Easy to drink, and not what youre used to drinking from SN.  Different, but good!

Poured into a tulip glass from a bomber. Appearance is a dark hazy brown with a dense cloud of nearly white foam. Head lingers the life of the beer. Aroma is figs, dates, prunes, and sweet malts. Has kind of a cheesy aroma to it as well. Taste is initially the prunes, dates, and figs but moves toward a creamy, malty yet tart presence. Smooth mouthfeel and very quaffable. Perhaps even a new favorite in the dubbel category. Very well put together.

The beer pours amber with an off white head. The aroma is sweet, light with Belgian yeast and dark fruits like an Abbey Dubbel does. It has the flavor of a bubbly lightly malty sweet Abbey Dubbel with the caramelized brown sugar as well. The mouthfeel is sensitive on the tongue, light smooth body.

Lightly hazy amber - fizzy, short-lived head - nose of yeast, dough, raisin, earth, black pepper, light oxidation - medium body and carbonation - moderately dry after some initial toffee and raisin - dusty yeast and mild oxidation through the middle - becomes quite peppery on the tail end, with a touch of acidity - lingering yeast - a little watery in the finish - good, but not worth the money.
Not the biggest dubbel fan but this is really nice.  Smooth with a hint of raisin and spice.  Slight burn that is pleasurable.  Pours an orange-ish brown.  Alcohol aroma to me.

Bottle - 750mL corked and caged. Cork comes out with a loud bass-heavy pop. Pours rusty brown, with a tall, dense beige head. Sweet malt, dark fruit, soft spice, dusty yeast, wood and cigar tobacco in the nose. Taste is dark fruit, brown sugar, sweet malt, caramel, tobacco, soft spice and dusty yeast notes. Body is medium-full with a vigorous carbonation. Ends with more dark fruit notes, toasted caramel, light spice, soft wood, tobacco and sweet malt.

Comes out of the tap a semi-transparent golden dark brown with a thick light tan head. Aroma is fruity, malty, woody and slightly sweet. Rich malty and fruity flavor has tones of oak, toffee and caramel. Fizzy texture leaves a persistent tingle and a fruity, sweet finish.
750ml corked and caged bottle, sweet fruit aroma, plums and currant. Bananas. The taste is much more subdued than the aroma, very yeasty. Almost a slight hop hint.

Airy, fluffy rust-colored head crests above a red-brown hued body. Musky, yeasty nose with some soap and phenol mixed in with a spritz of clove. Muskty, yeasty flavor, well-stated with some soap funk to add complexity. Solid.

Sweet aroma of red wine. Flavor is light, hoppy, flowery. There is some dark fruity maltiness, but it comes on very slowly, only notice able halfway through the glass. Mouthfeel is really light. Its good but not great. bottle from Frugal Macdoogal, Nashville.

draft @ redlight redlight.  Caramel aroma with spicy notes.  Pours a reddish amber with no head.  Rich and malty with some dark fruits, raisins and prunes, with hints of clove and cinnamon, with caramel malts.  Nice abbey dubbel.
750 from Beer Trappe. Lovely bottle. Taste is very much a dubbel with some caramel and malty flavor. Touch of sweetness. Some dried fruit. Well done.

750ml bottle.

Cork pops out of this bottle like a shot and pours a hazy brownish amber with a frothy beige head that leaves only traces of lacing.

Aroma is definitely sweet with lots of caramelized sugar and fruity esters.  Dark fruits in the form of raisins and plums with a noticeable doughy bread character and faint spices.

Taste also starts with the caramel malts and candy sugar with the breadiness in the background.  The taste is more balanced than the nose with the spices coming out in the finish especially. Really good taste.

The mouthfeel is light to medium bodied for the style with decent carbonation.

This is an excellent dubbel, one of the best Ive had in a long while.  Very complex but not overly sweet and super drinkable for a dark Belgian.  Great stuff.

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2014 Bottle.

First of all, the packaging is gorgeous. It just makes me want to try the bottle. Im sure its all cooked up by some ad agency and all, but dang it, it worked on me. Pours a buttery light copper with a decent though not extravagant head. Gently spicy nose is rather restrained relative to the flavor, which is a nice relatively-dry if quick-to-disperse dubbel. No sign of the alcohol in the mouthfeel though a moment later I can feel it warming my throat in a really nice way. Theres some house character here, Id lean toward to pinning on the hops though buggered if I know what is going on. Basically, you can tell its American dubbel, and not because it sucks, but because it tastes West-coast. What is clear that this is a very good dubbel and Im really enjoying the bottle even though Im not usually a huge fan of the style. One thing that is striking is that this beer doesnt have a single flaw that leaps out; theres some house character in that aspect as well.

Revisit in Santa Barbara summer 2014: spicy nose, fairly sweet flavor with lots of burnt caramel, again a bit more hop presence than some. Delicious example of a style that isnt a particular favorite of mine. 

tl;dr summary: the best US-made dubbel Ive had.

750ml bottle, corked and caged, enjoyed as the first beer of my bachelor party weekend, which ended up including a lot of beer.  Slightly hazy mahogany-brown in color with a well-formed and lasting light yellowish-tan head.  The aroma is nice and authentic abbey style, with dark fruits and spiciness along with candi sugar and toffee notes.  The flavor is spot-on for the style, with mild sweetness from malts that lend raisin, fig, and prune notes, as well as clove and pepper, and some Belgian yeast.  Medium-bodied with rather lively carbonation yet a mouthfeel on the smoother side.  Great classic if nothing terribly exciting.  I approve.
Pours chestnut into a trappist glass. White head with little retention recedes to hug rim. Sweet pit fruit and clove aromas. Clove and pit fruit from front to back. Lasting dry sweet caramel finish.

750ml Bottle. Pours a hazy deep brown with amber notes and a medium creamy  off white head that left sticky lacing.  Aroma of clove, black pepper, dark fruits, caramel, toffee and various fruity notes.  Flavor of black pepper, clove, caramel, toffee, nuts, dark fruits and tobacco.  Lacks the complexity of a true Belgian Dubbel. Might gain that with some age.

750 ml bottle from Bevmo. Pours a hazy dark brown color with a medium beige head that had good retention and some minor lacing. The aroma was moderately strong with cloves, pears, roasted grains and yeast. The flavor was rich and complex with roasted grains, molasses, wood, pears, dough, cloves,  mild spices, biscuit and a touch of cola. The palate was full and creamy smooth with soft carbonation. Finished long with lingering spices. Overall: Outstanding dubbel, I loved it-- note that it made a great accompaniment to Gouda cheese.

Poured from a bomber into a tiny plastic stein at Brew Fest in Athens, GA. This sat deep ruby beneath a pleasant head, though its tough to know whether that is intrinsic to the beer or merely the result of jostling en route to the festival grounds. Regardless, it looked nice, and tasted pleasant but not quite as nice as it looked. The flavors that should be there were there - stone fruit, robust yeast, a hint of quickbread - but it was neither as tasty nor as subtle as, say, Allagashs dubbel.

25.4 oz bottle.  Cloudy brown with a smooth beige head.  Nose is brown sugar, clove and dough; hints of wet wood.  Medium light with zesty carb.  Taste is caramel, smoky cantaloupe, bitter yeast and nutmeg.  A solid, if a bit uninspired, take on a dubbel.

Darky murky amber-brown color with a thin frothy head on top that stays for good.  Light Belgian yeast in the aroma with plum, sugary dried fruit, and caramelized apple.  I like this beer.  It has a spicy flavor that compliments the sweet dark fruit well.  Plums, raisins, dates comprise of the fruit flavors.  Slightly spritzy but not distracting or overdone.  Fairly light-bodied for a dubbel but the total package is still quite nice.  Could be a bit richer but no off flavors and definitely enjoyable.

Pours a light chocolate or ruby color with a thick caramel colored head. Smells lightly of brown sugar, with a light fruity touch. Thick on the palate, but very easy to drink. Tastes of a malty mix with an unidentified fruit flavor. Watch out, dont drink it too fast......

Man, I really wanted to like this more than I did. Brown, with a big foamy beige head. Faint aroma - kinda fruity, maybe some leathery notes? Im not . bitter than I was expecting/sure/ Flavor is also a bit too understated. Finish was more bitter than I expected.

Nose of dates, bananas, and a bit of hickory. Flavor profile is similar with a bit of toffee. Finish is malty yet very short lived. Everything about this beer is good enough to drink, yet nothing about it is outstanding.  It is thin in every way and the finish barely exists. If there was more of every thing it would benefit greatly.
Amber, very good head.  Definite Belgian beer aroma with spices coming out in the drink.  Finish isnt very bitter.  A good Belgian style.

750 ml bottle.  Pours a deep rusty brown color with a medium sized cream colored-light beige head.  Aroma of light bananas, cloves, sweet malt and caramelized sugar.  Taste of light dark fruit(dates, figs, prunes), mild cloves, faint banana and caramelized sugar.

750ml bottle served in a chalice. The beer is a dark cherrywood color with a off-white head that stayed as a thin layer which was fueled by rising carbonation bubbles. The aroma is on the sweeter side with dark fruit and mild yeast. The taste is very good, sweet dark fruit upfront with a light yeasty twang on the somewhat dry finish. The beer is medium bodied with a light, crisp feel. Overall this is a very delightful and most enjoyable Dubbel. I look forward to the other beers from this series.

Bottle...  Poured deep, dark brown/ruby-ish with a thick khaki head.  Some good Belgian yeast spice on the nose with sweet, malted grains.  Flavors of toasted caramel, butterscotch, lots of malt with a hint of hop floralness to balance.  Dark fruit nots like prunes and raisins, with some yeast spiciness that lent itself to cloves and big time fruit esters.
Deep red amber-brown.  Aroma of biscuit, gingerbread, spice, candied fruit.  Smooth roasted/toasted malt flavor with a little dryness at the end.  Mild sweetness and baked bread.

A mighty pop when removing the cork, but thankfully no liquid explosion along with it.  Pours hazy amber/brown with a dense beige head. The aroma has toasty brown-like malt, light brown sugar, light spice, hint of nuts, restrain yeastiness and some toastiness to it.  Medium body with a lot of frothy mouth-filling carbonation.  The flavor starts out with much of what the aroma suggested, but it is drier and spicier.  There are hints of anise and grains of paradise qualities and is quite peppery.  The finish has a nice blend of spiciness and malts.  As the beer warms there are lots of date and fig notes showing through.  This strikes me as being unique but very approachable.  It is not as sweet or yeasty as most in the style from either Belgium or the states.  Very enjoyable take on a dubbel.

Pours a rich ruby color with thick, frothy, off-white head.  Aroma is of light malt, Belgian spice, dark fruits, ad toasted malt showing up in the finish.  Taste is the same.  Well balanced for the style.

Thanks for sharing, bro.  Pours a dirty red-brown color with a medium frothy off-white head.  Aroma is Belgian spice, plum, raisin, and candied sugar.  Taste is much the same, well balanced for a style that I dont generally care for.
Dark pour. Was expecting a sweeter beer just from the darkness but was mildly sweet. A very nice dubbel that has high drinkability. Good beer.

750ml bottle, split with ablackshear.  Pours a deep brown color with light tan head.  Aroma is clove, spicy belgian yeast.  Medium on the palate with lively carbonation.  Flavor is sweet, spicy, yeasty, and a little malty.  A very good dubbel, but not as complex as some of the Belgian versions.

Bottle.

Head is initially large, fizzy/frothy, light brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is hazy dark amber to medium brown, bottle conditioned.

Aroma is moderately malty (toasted bread/nuts, caramel), lightly hoppy (herbs), with notes of gum, .brown sugar.

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation, lightly to moderately alcoholic.

An uninspired, dull, simple example. Not much going on in the nose, just the most basic Belgian brown ale notes.  Watery and plain in the mouth.
On tap. Poured a copperish color with a smaller sized head. Aromas of caramel, dark fruits, and some breadiness. Tastes of caramel, dark fruits, bread, and some spices.

On tap at Threepenny in Montpelier. A nice beer. Clear red, thin white head. Malty with candi sugar and raisin in the mix, a slight yeasty bite at the finish. The tastes are all there, but the one thing I found was its a bit thin for the flavors. Finishes slightly watery.

Tallahassee, Fl - Market Square Liquors - 750 ml caged cork bottle. Pours a nice dark copper with a silky smooth off-white head. Aroma is pleasant with some light brandy accents, a touch of licorice and some bready notes. Flavor is mellow, with some nutty accents, a hint of licorice and just a breif whisper of some date-like fruitiness. Not overflowing with flavor, just smooth drinking and warming. Mouthfeel has just the right amount of spritziness.

iRate.  On tap at Papago.  Pours a thin mahogany color with a trim beige head.  Smells of hops, Belgian yeast, and a little shoe polish.  Tastes of further yeast, pretzel dust, fruit cocktail, black tea, and some cardboard from the malt.  Decent, but not something I plan on returning to.

750ml bottle.  murky brown under a large, creamy, stable, cream colored head.  big sweet aroma with brown sugar and caramel.  body is medium with a foamy palate.  flavor has notes of brown sugar and some peachy fruits in the finish with is nice.  flavor is not a sweet as the aroma suggests and aroma and flavor or quite different by the aroma lending to caramel and flavor is more fruity.
From a bottle poured a dark amber color with a fair amount of head.  Light sweet malty flavor with a lingering finish.

Bottle from Whole Foods, Vienna.  Cork opened with a very loud pop.  Not a gusher, but lots of carbonation.  Pours an opaque brown with an orange tint and a thick and fluffy tan head.  Fruity aroma with with hints of chocolate and raisins.  Flavor is sweet with lots of cherry and chocolate.  Bitter finish with a bit of alcohol.  Overall a nice dubbel.
Dark garnet brown with a creamy tan head. Sweet malty and caramel aroma and taste with toffee notes and a roasted grain finish.

On draught a bit too cold at Aces & Ales. Opaque dark brown with a slight tan head and lace of very fine bubbles. Mild raisiny aromas. Big body with solid mouthfeel. Restrained Belgian notes, dry brown sugar hints. Tasty but a bit to "clean" for a rich Dubble.
Had it on tap alongside a Meredsous 8 and St. B 12 and ti didnt hold a candle. A decent beer but muddled as far as dubbels/bsdas go.

Dark mahogany, clear if held up to the light, with a two-finger tan head, solid retention and very nice lace. Modest aromas of bready malt, rich dark fruit, yeast and brown sugar. Moderate sweetness from doughy bread, raisins, plums and figs, and caramelized sugars. A hint of floral hops bitterness ensures a nice balance. Creamy smooth mouthfeel, lively carbonation, and a very pleasant dark fruit sweetness in the finish. Great stuff, plus it makes you feel good about yourself for helping the monks rebuild their monastery.

a medium cloudy amber with copper in the middle, a big and nice looking light tan head, great retention and lacing... nose of yeast and cloves, a hint of spice, a light dark fruits, a little to generic... the taste is much better than the nose, a very light dubbel in feel and taste but some night sweet caramel notes, sugar some nice dark fruits, very drinkable, a little sour note on the finish... besides a light mouthfeel the carbonation is great... impressed, Id have again.

From a 750ml bottle from Picks Liquors. Pours an earthy maroon or deep brown. Very dark and murky. Tan head that sat there for a while. Has a roasty caramel aroma. Taste is medium sweeteness with a slight aftertaste of bitterness and salt. Palate shows a medium bodied beer. Creamy and oily with very lively carbonation. Like a soda fountain that stopped pouring they syrup. Slightly sweet and finish lasting over 15 seconds. Overall its a pretty good beer. Sierra Nevada is pretty proud of this one considering the price. 11.49 for a 750ml. Although, I consider the cost into the fact that this is a charity beer, with some of the proceeds being donated back to the monks who helped make it.
Not bad - doesnt taste very belgian. Very clean, nice malt body and dark fruit. The yeast just seems wrong.
Poured dark maroon with good lacinng smelled earty raisony and malty tasted ok with weak boring aftertaste

(750ml bottle)  Pours a deep amber-brown body with medium beige head.  Aroma of caramel, raisins, banana, light leather, and clove.  Flavor of raisins, caramel, clove, maple, yeast, dates, and light pepper.

Draft. Pours clear brown with a small biege head. Aroma is apple juice, caramel, sugar, clove. Flavor is sweet with a big apple juice flavor. Palate is a bit watery and bland but nothing offensive here.

Poured a hazy brown with a thick,  tan foam. The aroma is of yeast, malt, slight banana. Big mouthfeel for a dubbel but its lovely. Yeasty, banana notes and subdued esters (compared to its Belgian brothers) make this an easy drinking, food friendly dubbel.

750, corked and baled. Pours a clear and very dark amber with a loose and creamy tan head. Stringy, sudsy lace too. Caramel and pepper on the nose, with a bit of clove. Gives it almost a tangy aluminum effect, but that would be a trick of the light. Creamy medium body with light carb. Caramel, pepper, and a bit of clove on the mid-palate. Mild bready finish. Not bad.

750 mL bottle.  Pours a hazed caramel color with an off-white head.  Aromas of red apple, grape, caramel, a little banana and a little nuttiness.  Clean flavor with grapes, red apple, and nuttiness.  Later some yeasty cloves come into play with a little peppery spiciness.  Several flavors shift around as it warms.  Certainly a high quality dubbel.

UPDATED: APR 7, 2011 750 ml corked and caged bottle into a Trappist glass. Pours a slightly hazy amber with a medium beige head that falls pretty quick; leaves a collar of foam. Aroma is peppery, like cotton candy and quite grainy; I do smell clove in the mix, as well as bread. Taste is lightly sweet with no bitterness. Very Trappist-like. Carbonation and body are medium, mouthfeel is creamy. A little dry. Nice beer, but even though I say its very Trappist-like, theres something missing here to make it truly great.

Draft.  Small beige head, clear garnet body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, candi sugar/cotton candy, caramel, raisin, some banana.  Taste is moderately sweet, maple, candi sugar, raisin, some caramel, banana.  Low carbonation, medium body, some stickiness.
OOoh.  A faint carob flavor amid the raisins and yeast in the aroma.  The body excellent.  The carob is present in the body with a wonderfully blended raisin and yeast character.
Bomber. Pours opaque amber brown, thin off white head. Aroma is faint: malt and dried fruit. Flavor is meaty, tangy, yeasty; decent body and carbonation. A little more yeasty than Id care for.

Slightly hazed red-brown pour with an off-white head. Aroma of toast, spice, caramel, candy, nuts, black pepper and raisins. The taste is mildly sweet, toasty, nutty, caramel malt and a bit yeasty. Body is medium with moderate carbonation. Nothing overdone here, a very drinkable and enjoyable dubbel. Slightly noticeable alcohol as it warms. Well done.

Bottle.  Clear dark brown pour, lasting thick carbonation and a nice sweet brown sugar/malt aroma.  Flavor is light vegetal malt, some sweet sugar and finished thin and watery with a little spice on the aftertaste.  Not worth the $10 I paid for it.

Red brown color with a small, light tan head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of caramel malts, dark fruits, some nuts, spices, and light alcohol.  Taste of much of the same, caramel, dark fruits, and spices, with a soft finish.
Nice brown, murky appearance. Bready, yeasty, nice interpretation of a dubbel. A little thin for me, but a nice beer.

750mL bottle purchased at the Davis Food Co-Op.  Aroma has initial fruitiness with hints of berries, before it becomes a little more roasted and burnt.  Light chocolate is also there with some yeast esters, too.  Moderately hazy amber body with a nice cream-colored medium head.  Fizzy carbonation and decent head retention.  Starts sweet, with plenty of candy and chewy malts.  Some caramel and chocolate hints come through fairly strongly in the middle.  Becomes more toasted with a hint of roastiness towards the end.  The yeast surprisingly does not impart too much flavoring in this, which is usually my main beef with American brewers doing Belgian styles.  As a matter of fact, this is on the other end of the spectrum, where the yeast is minimal.  This is kind of like a chewy, nutty brown ale that is unfiltered and brewed with a clean Belgian yeast.
To me this is a world class dubbel. Everything you would want in a dubbel is here except that it was brewed in the USA. It is one great beer and Im proud it is brewed in America.

Bottle from Taylors Market, Sacramento. Pours dark copper with a nice beige head and a fruity toffee aroma. There is a hearty caramel malt flavor with the standard dubbel tastes, candi sugar, raisin and spice. This is a good representation of the abbey dubbel style.

draft at the gingerman norwalk came a coppery brown color with a thin covering of light brown head. aroma has a nice yeast, earthy malt, spices, and some sweetness. mouth feel is medium and has low side carbonation. flavor has a good malted body, spicy yeast, some earthy qualities, and some dry chocolate. interesting beer with good yeasty character.

750 ML bottle purchased at BevMo in Redding, CA. AROMA / BOUQUET: Sierra Nevada have accomplished hard to produce bouquets at the same time: raisiny yet slightly grassy! Esters come through really well, with citrusy undertones. Hops are subdued but evident. APPEARANCE: Pours a medium dark brown, lively light brown head, with great lacing. The head is largely spaced with bubbles that collase in the appropiate amount of time.  TASTE: Medium bodied, definitive pepperiness, with overtones of cacao. PALATE / MOUTHFEEL: slightly sticky due to the Belgian candi sugar used in the brewing process. Fizzy carbonation, but I have always liked "fizzy" carbonated Belgian beers. The finish is a subdued nutty / pepperiness. Overall, a great Dubbel. The brewers at Sierra Nevada have taken their skills and created a good first offering. I see this Dubbel morphing into something greater as they receive feedback from beer tasters from around the world. Id love to know what the Belgians think of this one... Reminds me a bit of Ommegang Abbey Ale.

Excellent Dubel! And I usually dont like Dubbels. Sweet with dry finish, notes of dark fruits, little coffee and some euro-tasting candy. A bit like a coffee candy - but so much more - notes of faint tannins, wood and cork.

Bottle thanks to swalden28. Poured amber with an off white head. Aroma was orange, dark fruit, corriander, and caramel. Flavor was spice, pepper, slight citrus, and orange. Body was light with soft fizzy carbonation.

Bottle. Pours a hazy brown with beige head. Aroma of some dark fruit, citris peel, caramelized sugar, subtle horse blanket. Flavor is much the same with a balanced sweetness and subtle earthy notes as well. Medium body with soft, fizzy carbonation. Good Stuff!

Pours hazy dark amber brown with a frothy long lasting beige head. Aroma is much milder than expected with fruit-raisin, plum, peach and light Belgian yeast noticeable. Taste is also not what I expected, not to say that its bad, but this is certainly not as extreme as most Sierra beers. Nice sweet malty body with the Belgian yeast adding good fruitiness. The alcohol is hidden. This is the only Dubbel my dad has ever said he enjoyed the flavor of, so that is saying something for the way it is set apart from other dubbels. When I first tasted this beer, I was looking for something more, now that I am halfway through the bottle, I am thoroughly enjoying it and its easy drinking nature. Very smooth texture.

750mL from Jubilation. Oh I like this. Aroma is super nice. Some light flowery aromatics-like a wit in many ways. Enough dirt. Flavor starts out fresh, Moves into some bready, toasty malt. Finish should be a little less bitter.

Cloudy brown copper pours. Fluffy off tan head. Nose is full of spice: herbal and hoppy. Clove and black pepper without a doubt. Pepper really added a nice fresh breaking up other flavors aspect to the beer. Lighter in body than I would have originally thought. Maybe its just because this beer is still pretty fresh and hoppy. The fruit and malt profiles seem firm and tight for the moment. I think this beer will benefit from at least a few years of bottle age. It certainly improved in the glass over the course of an hour or so.

Bottle from midtown. Pours a murky copper brown with a thick porous head that dissipates to a dense rententive ring. Aroma of belgian esters a brown sugar. Medium bodied, with a slight wateriness in texture. Flavor is pretty straight forward-raisens, brown sugar, belgian malts- but with no complexity. Finishes yeasty, musty, with a hint of spicy phenols.  Not bad, but not nearly as complex as Corsondonk, Westmalle, Chimay, etc.

750 ml. Cloudy, deep amber body. Thick, frothy beige head, slowly diminishing. Fruity aroma of raisin, plum with a hint of strawberry. Notes of grain and sugar. The flavor is moderately to heavily sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes moderately sweet and lightly to moderately bitter with an acidic tanginess in the aftertaste. Medium body, watery texture turning creamy, lively carbonation. Tastes of cola with a slight note of clove and some Vitamin B (just like SN pale ale). What I missed in this was the mustiness and slight funkiness of a good Belgium dubbel. Nor is the sweetness under control as it is in a Chimay Red, for example. Just OK.

Pours mahogany brown with rusty red highlights and a fading beige head.  Aroma of caramel, raisins, clove, cinnamon,  and maybe some rye or bread component.  Flavor of caramel, earth, raisin, brown sugar, cinnamon, cloves, grass, and even a bit of pepper.  Finish dries out with wood, burned grass, hay and toast with a peppery hop fade.  Its a bit sweet and slightly chewier than many other abbeys, but that only makes me want this one more.  Medium bodied with a bit of noticable chewiness and high carbonation that tingles.  This is a great dubbel IMO with lot of complexities and aspects to enjoy.  I hope to buy more before the stores run out.

750 ml bottle.  Brown pour, with frothy light tan head. Dark fruits.. fig, raisin, stone fruit, light candy sugar sweetness, light yeast, orange peel, clove, and pepper.  The mouthfeel is not heavy which I appreciate, and overall its not too sweet.  Excellent for an American dubbel.

Bottle:   So it somewhat looks the part, brownish, a little murky, nice big frothy tannish head, fairly decent lacing.   Soft bready notes, some even softer dark pitted fruit, dates, figs, etc.   Not real heavy, thankfully, flavorful without being over the top.   Tastes authentic enough, but perhaps not as basement like.   Could stand to be a bit thicker, but its alright.   Cant complain about the finish, clean, a little too quick tho.   Sweeter and less musty than Belgian examples, but still tasty enough.   Add a bit more body and dankness, cut down on the sugar, that would be the biz.

I had this on tap at Tustin Brewing company.

If I were to characterize this beer in one word, it would light. The mouthfell was thin, IMO, for a dubbel. It also lacked the richness I expect from a dubbel. It was sweet but in a one dimensional sort of way. It wasnt complex.

750mL bottle, purchased at Bottle Barn. Pours a medium cola-brown color with golden edges; creamy, fine-bubbled light-tan head that fades pretty quickly. Basic aroma of cola, raisins, and brown sugar; rather bland. Medium body; medium to medium-high carbonation; no overt alcohol, but maybe a light vinous contribution; a touch watery at the perimeter. Basic cola, overripe sweetness, brown sugar, and raisins form the core of things; rather sweet and insipid overall; some modest clove and pepper contributions, but the focus sits on the cola- and sugar-driven core; reasonably high acidity; not bad or even flawed, but anything like Corsendonk would spank it. Heavily focused on a rather bland (even slightly stale and papery) malt character. Moderate finish, with more of those papery notes, cola, and brown sugar coming out; slightly sweet.

Draft at Toad in the Hole. Hazy brown with diminishing yellow head. Minuscule root beer scent. Flavor is equally hollow, resembling watered-down diet cola with some chalkiness, and utterly lacking in yeast-derived interestingness. Light in body, though drips are surprisingly sticky; a hint of chlorophenol completes this ouroboros of disappointment.

Pours a beautiful unclear brown with a nice tan head.  Aroma is sweet malts and berries, with a little booze.  Taste is incredibly complex... bright citrus, dark ripe fruits, caramel, raisins, and medium roasted malts. Finish is long, malty, fruity, boozy, and warming. You couldve blindfolded me and told me I was drinking a trappist dubbel.  This beer is very impressive.

Bottle: Murky, reddish-brown with a tan bubbly head.  Wow - a wonderful aroma full of richer than normal Werthers Originals, genuine maple syrup, and a hint of citrus zest.  Smooth and mellow flavors of figs and dates.  Nice. Thanks Indiana_Red.
Nice brown pour.  Big tan head.  Aroma of dates, raisin bread, yeast, brown sugar and spices.  Flavor is lightly sweet, yeast, dates, figs, raisins. Very good.

750ml bottle corked and caged. Served in a chalice. Opened with a big pop. Lots of carbonation. Poured a mahogany with a couple of fingers of fine bubbled, off white head. Spice from the yeast and some dark malt sweetness in the aroma. Medium bodied. Nice spicy flavor with clove. Not overly sweet as some dubbels can be. Some carmelized sugar and dark fruit. Very easy drinking. I liked this a lot.

(750ml bottle).  Pours hazy cola color with nice beige head.  Appropriate carbonation.  Aroma has candied sugar, black pepper, ripe pit fruit. Taste has some malt sweetness, but not over the top.  A hit of bitterness in there. Medium bodied with an oily texture.  Smooth finish where the pepper is distinctive to me.  This beer is pretty nicely balanced, if a little subdued.

Bottle from total wine.   Pours dark brown with a tan head.   Smell is toasty and sweet.  Little bit of hops.  Taste is smooth and fresh.  Light carbonation but a very high drinkablility.   Really good beer.  Not surprising either.   Has a good drinking quality that many Belgians lack.

Dark caramel brown in the glass with a thick and frothy beige head.  Aroma is predominately clove with light spice, candied sugar, and sweet malt.  Taste is rich, layered sweet malt, raisin, candied sugar, and a tingling spiciness (perhaps the pepper noted in the beers description).  Lively feel in the mouth with prickly carbonation.  Great beer.

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2011 Pours an initially fluffy, tan head that fades into a lasting ring and a wonderful, clear, copper body.  Aroma is malty and caramel sweet.  Flavor is malty, caramel, some dark fruit, slightly roasted, clove, some spice.  Slightly dry finish with a lingering fruity note.
Bottle. Pours walnut brown creamy tan head. Malt sour aroma, malty, slightly sour taste, watlnut/hazelnut aftertaste. Very solid beer, and a very nice americanisation of the style.

Best domestic Abbey Ive had yet. Solid structure. Subtle notes of spices and dried orange peel, and heavier notes of tobacco  and clove. Loosely retained two finger off tan head. Dried orange, earth and other integrated fruit notes dominate the palate with some pepper laced through the finish.
Not that it makes a difference but solid label too.

750 c&c. Pours orangish brown. Little head retention.  Nose is just slightly yeasty with banana and clove but then filled with a bunch of interesting things like dried orange peel, lychee, spices,carrot cake w/ cream cheese frosting...flavors are delicate yet impressively refined..this is as pure an abbey dubbel as any american beer I can remember...rather than use an overly aggressive and obvious belgian strain and loads of candi sugar and whatever other crap american brewers usually throw together for their so called dubbels, this thing is remarkably restrained yet ingeniusly crafted...soft malts combine with the delicate belgian esters sprinkled with relaxing citrus peel and spice, laid upon a very drinkable medium body..its really a gloriously made american dubbel. You dont find many if any of these, which is why I rarely if ever drink this style...but id come back to this in a heart beat.

750 c&c from Taylors Market in Sacramento, CA. Cork broke. Used wine opener, got a pop. Pours very dark and ruddy copper or mayhap mahogany, with a 3 finger creamy beige head. Nice aroma of mild darker fruits. Near full bodied. My goodness it is extremely fruity. Starts like strawberry then  goes on to spice, and raisin/plum. It certainly is not bitter, its far from sticky sweet. A little pepper comes out as the fruit wears away. Not so dark and plummy as it might have been, but its fair brilliant ale. So..... Ovila Quad - gotta have that.

Sampled on 3/19/2011. This abbey dubbel pours a slightly hazy medium amber brown color. Medium sized white foamy head with decent lacing and nice retention. The aroma is caramel. dark fruit, figs and sweet. A medium bodied dubbel. The malts are fruity and sweet, touch of figs, raisins and dark fruit. Nice bright yeasts. Good carbonation, Very smooth taste. Very easy drinking. Nicely balanced. I am assuming this is the first Belgian Style beer that Sierra Nevada has made and its an awesome first effort. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.
